subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. Does the minister recall announcing funding under the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program for the Frankston Community Arts Centre on 15 September last year? Does he recall telling local journalists that the lobbying by Dunkley MP Bruce Billson was a critical factor in securing the $1.5 million grant, as was reported in the Frankston Standard on 21 September? Precisely what weight did the minister and Senator Hill give the intervention of the party room colleagues in vulnerable coalition seats in their deliberations over the allocation of the $70 million fund? Was this Frankston grant one of the 16 bottom drawer projects?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —First of all, I do not know any Mr Bruce Billston. I am surprised that someone who has been trying to chase the seat of Holt for some years would not at least pass through Dunkley from time to time and see a few signposts up. Obviously you did not need any assistance from the local member. Certainly, there was no shortage of people offering their comments on their pet projects—and that is not confined to our side of the chamber. I suspect that most of you were asleep at the wheel and did not bother. That was the real problem. You were scurrying around taking instructions from the ACTU when you should have been out in the community looking at what sorts of projects there were that might have deserved support. That would have been a lot more productive.

answer.para: I certainly do recall paying a visit down there and I remember that it struck me at the time that it completely vindicated the objective decision we had made on the merits of the project. That is always very important. I think that was one of a number of the projects that would withstand close scrutiny—in fact, all of the projects would. That is critically important if the Labor Party wants to continue to rabbit on about this issue. I have to say it must have been a bit gloomy this morning when the old tactics committee got together and said, `What have we got to show for yesterday?' There were five questions on the subject, and all they got was a bit of a run in the Aus which confirmed the proposition that I put yesterday, and that was that you do not slavishly follow the advice of bureaucrats.

Let us get back to the main game here. If the Labor Party are critical of these projects, do they object to the restoration of the Great Synagogue Tower in the Sydney seat of Sydney? Do they object to the restoration of the Polly Woodside and Federation Tapestry in the seat of Melbourne? Do they object to the restoration of the Naval Stores and the Commissariat Museum in a Brisbane marginal seat? Do they object to the National Wool Museum in Corio, or the development of the Tuggeranong Homestead in Canberra? One could go on. The fact is that Senator Faulkner put his very big foot in this some days ago when he claimed that there were 16 shonky projects. All I can suggest to you is that when you get together for the post mortem afterwards you start to do a bit of serious homework, you go through these projects and try and make some judgments—you might even get Senator Collins to visit a couple more of them. She might even find out who the local members are, and then you can start to make a judgment about whether these projects were worth while. When you do that, I think you will find that they all stack up very well indeed.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that he said that Mr Billson was a critical factor. Secondly, I remind the minister that I asked whether this Frankston centre was one of the 16 bottom drawer projects. He knows what I mean. Finally, isn't it a fact that the ministers had their own points system employed on the 16 occasions when they rejected official advice and that their scheme involved the electoral pendulum and a highlighter pen?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —No, no, I think you have to go back about three or four years to find that sort of system in operation, and I think we all know who invented that scheme. Of course, it sounds as though nothing has been learnt from that fiasco. The fact that Mr Billson might have been critical of the project really did not come into our considerations. I am interested that the experts in bottom fishing on the other side somehow think that because we exercise independent judgment we are rejecting advice. This is just a canard that has been peddled by the likes of Senator Faulkner for weeks on end. This must be about the fifth occasion that he has tried to get this issue off the ground. It has gone nowhere for the simple reason that everyone who has studied it understands that there is a discretion there. What the bureaucrats actually said was, `If you want to take the cut-off point that we insert arbitrarily, you only need to look at 114.' We actually did our homework and looked at the lot. (Time expired)

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of former distinguished Tasmanian senator, the Hon. Michael Tate. I welcome you on your return visit to the Senate.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. The minister will be aware of the need to further improve communications services in regional and rural Australia. Will the minister inform the Senate of any recent advances in this area and is the minister aware of any alternative policy proposals? What would be the impact if these alternatives were implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We are certainly aware of the need to improve services in regional areas. The tragedy, of course, is that only one-half of the parliament seems to have the same view. We only have to go back to the early 1990s when that extraordinary deal was made to phase out the analog service without any replacement in prospect, and then, to compound the felony, to sign up to legal agreements which would have exposed the Commonwealth to hundreds of millions of dollars in damages. The idea of simply doing a deal without having any idea of what might follow was probably the height of short-sighted stupidity, and demonstrates without doubt that the Labor Party was not interested in letting the technologies sort themselves out or in trying to develop a long-term policy approach.

—Do not get excited—you will get a cheap phone in the very near future because I am about to confirm that today Telstra has announced the new pricing structure and services for the CDMA network. Senator Allison, I know, will be particularly interested in that, because dual mode handsets will be available for $69. I am not here to spruik, but that does sound, on the face of it, like a pretty good deal. I am particularly pleased about the fact that we do now have world-class technology available in competition with GSM, which in itself is world-class, and for the first time we will have a very decent range of competitive alternatives in the marketplace.

answer.para: By the end of next year CDMA will be available in all analog areas, and Telstra has confirmed that it plans to extend CDMA into areas not previously covered by analog. Telstra analog customers will be able to connect to CDMA with no connection fee. I do not need to remind the Senate of the inherent superiority of digital services, but certainly CDMA and GSM will offer services such as advanced message bank, call forwarding, calling number display and call waiting, and, when we get to the third generation, even Senator Lundy will be able to work out which button to press to be able to access the Internet. You will have your own flat panel screen that will fold out and you will be able to play to your heart's content.

While you are taking time off to claim for your RSI disability, can I entreat the Labor Party to simply reconsider the Luddite position they adopted at the last election. Remember Senator Schacht? This is his great claim to fame, apart from being the almost endorsed candidate for Makin—and we wish him well in that regard. Makin will be a very tough call, but if anyone from Labor can do it, Senator Schacht can. But his lasting contribution to ensuring the Labor Party lost the last election was to bag the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund. There was about $150 million left in it, but they said they would freeze it. That came on top of being opposed to the Natural Heritage Trust Fund a few years back, and when the Telstra bill came up in the chamber only a matter of a few months ago they were at it again. It was tragic. Senator Boswell had a field day going all around Queensland—he even went outside his home state—pointing out the fact that we had a whole series of initiatives to benefit regional and rural Australia and the Labor Party opposed every one of them. That is the tragedy: they have no interest at all in attending to the needs of regional and rural Australia. Today also happens to be the day on which the final four per cent will get their digital data connections—very good news for rural Australia.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. Is the minister aware that the City of Maroondah was initially informed that they would be advised of the success or otherwise of their application for funding from the Federation Cultural and Heritage Fund for the Maroondah Heritage Trust project in November 1998? Can he confirm that he announced the $2 million funding for the project on Wednesday, 23 September? Is he aware that the member for Deakin, Phil Baressi, was therefore able to use the funding announcement as the lead item in a newsletter distributed to every household in his electorate on the Tuesday before the election, and in a how-to- vote leaflet on the Friday? If that wasn't the reason for fast-tracking the announcement, what was?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is definitely time for re-education classes. You cannot be so out of touch that you have two Victorian senators who have no idea how to pronounce the names of House of Representatives members. It is a truly embarrassing situation. You really do need some remedial coaching. I would have thought that, at the very least, these matters would come up at the strategy meetings where they would say, `How are we going to knock off the member for Deakin?' or `How are we going to deal with the member for Dunkley?' But if you do not even know who that is, it makes it very difficult indeed. At least you did not pronounce it `Mr Barassi', which I would have thought was almost on the tip of Senator Conroy's tongue.
—Senator Ray would have known.
—Senator Alston, please return to the question.

—I think the question had something to do with whether I was aware of some advice that Maroondah council received. I do not know why I would be particularly aware of any advice they received. Certainly, I can recall the announcement of a number of very good projects at a time when I think there was a particular interest in those projects. As Senator Conroy well knows, the guidelines in relation to the caretaker convention make it perfectly plain that, as long as the decisions are taken before the election is called, there is no particular significance attached to making those announcements at a time that might be most suitable to all concerned. All I can say to Senator Conroy is this: you ought to take a visit out there—and apologise to Mr Baressi when you do—drive past his electorate office so you get it fixed in your mind, then go on to the particular project area and ask them what they think of it. Ask them whether they are objecting violently to being a fortunate beneficiary of limited federal government funds—ask them whether they have any objection. Or you, as an outside objective observer, can come along to the Senate and tell us what was wrong with that particular project.

answer.para: The problem is, as Senator Faulkner said yesterday, in letting a very big cat out of a very smelly bag, you are not really interested in outcomes. You are not interested in the merits of the projects; you are simply interested in running around trying to get a dead cat off the map—a dead cat that has been buried for at least 12 months.

talk.start.para: —It's your dead cat.

—No, a dead cat for you. It is something that, as far as we are concerned, is smelling like roses because they were all projects that deserved to be supported. They were ones that were very much on the live list and we chose the best from those available.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Why does the minister persist in ignoring the caretaker convention that `it is desirable, if the decisions concern significant initiatives, that they be announced in advance of the caretaker period in order to avoid controversy'?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Do I take it from that that Senator Conroy is saying that this was a significant project? I think we can proceed from that to saying that Senator Conroy, even though he might not have been out there personally, is now telling us that he regards that as a significant project, which I presume means that he thinks it deserved to be funded. If that is right, that is very good news indeed, because that is the first time that anyone on your side of the chamber has actually been prepared to come out and endorse one of these projects. Why can't you look at some more of these projects and come to similar conclusions? Senator Conroy presumably has some trace of cultural heritage in him. He goes to Victoria Park from time to time; he must know what it means. All he has got to do is go little bit further. In fact, if you go along that road, along Johnson Street, it will take you out to the Maroondah Highway. It is an extra half-hour or so. It is probably not within your union fiefdom—(Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Would the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs advise the Senate of the Howard government's substantial commitment to improving literacy standards for indigenous students? Would he also advise the Senate of support for the government's commitment to this strategy?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Eggleston for what is a very important question. For too long now literacy levels for indigenous students have been at too low a level. In fact, they have been at a much lower level than for students in the wider community. So it is entirely appropriate that the Commonwealth has set a goal for 2004 of equality of outcomes in indigenous education. To show this government's commitment, we have committed in this budget $1.1 billion worth of initiatives over the next five years in relation to indigenous education. We will maintain funding for indigenous education at record levels.

answer.para: We acknowledge that there is much to be done—the opposition might just care to listen to this—in the area of indigenous education. We are on the right track, but it is not just us who are saying we are on the right track. Just take the words of Mr Bob Collins, a former Labor senator, who has a long experience with indigenous affairs. He said that the government's measures were right on the mark in relation to indigenous education. His review team visited no fewer than 44 schools with Aboriginal students, and the feedback that he obtained from parents and teachers in relation to our initiatives was overwhelming support. Mr Collins went on further to state that he believes that the government's plan of obtaining educational partnerships with local communities and improving attendance at school is crucial, and the government is in entire agreement with this. We will also take into account the suggestion of in-service training for non-indigenous teachers before they go into the field and their teaming with indigenous teachers. This the government regards as a crucial point as well.

talk.start.para: —How are you going to get the money to the schools? How are you going to get over the Northern Territory government?
—Senator Carr, you are out of order.

—We have also earmarked an additional $14 million for improving indigenous students' school attendance over the same period. We are dedicated to closing the gap between indigenous educational outcomes and those of the wider community. We are now requiring education providers funded through the Commonwealth supplementary indigenous programs for the years 2001 to 2004 to focus on accelerating the closure of that gap, particularly so in relation to literacy, numeracy and attendance at school. These are, after all, the basics of achieving the outcomes that we are after.

answer.para: It is a crying shame that in 1999 we have to think of even setting a target of 2004 for achieving equality in indigenous educational outcomes. But we are set on that path, and it is the right track. In fact, Senator Ridgeway was quoted in the paper today as saying, `You have got to break that welfare cycle. It can't be a case of the self-defeating cycle of dependency.' That is what this government is all about. We are seeking to achieve that in our national indigenous literacy and numeracy strategy. This is a well thought-out, practical strategy whereby we can give those basic qualifications and abilities to indigenous students to go further.

There are some achievements worth while noting. We have come a long way and we still have a long way to go, but let us look at the figures for indigenous students in Australia today. We have a record number of indigenous students enrolling in tertiary education, 7,789 students enrolled in 1998, and a record number of about 5,000 in indigenous traineeships.

talk.start.para: —Senator Crossin seems to have something to say about this, but what we are saying is that this is an achievement. Give credit where it is due. As I said, there is much to be done, and we are set on the task of achieving that target by 2004. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, the minister for communications. Isn't it true that the government announced 39 grants from the FCHP Program in the course of the last election campaign? How does he explain the fact that 33 out of 39 grants were in coalition seats, 12 in seats that were One Nation vulnerable and two in the ACT, where the President of the Senate, Senator Reid, was under strong challenge from the Democrats? How does he explain that of the 28 successful grants which were left for announcement to 15 October, well after the election, 14 were in Labor seats and three in seats held by Independents. Was the FCHP Program designed as a pork barrelling program from the outset or was it just manipulated by the relevant ministers and the government for political advantage?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The short answers to those questions are no and no. Just in case anyone might think that Senator Faulkner is making the point that there is something wrong with announcing projects during an election campaign, perhaps I could draw the Senate's attention to a press release dated 12 February 1996 under the name of Senator John Faulkner—
—And tell us whether the shadow minister was consulted under the caretaker convention.
—Senator Faulkner!
—Tell us whether the shadow minister was consulted in accordance with the caretaker convention.
—Order! Senator Faulkner! You are totally out of order, having asked a question, to be sitting and shouting across the table to the minister answering it. You will abide by the standing orders.
—But I am asking him whether—
—There is an appropriate time for you to take a supplementary question if you wish to do so.
—It does hurt, doesn't it? You can understand why he is exquisitely sensitive.
—Tell us whether the shadow minister was consulted—that is the point.
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—No, the point is not that at all. Let us be quite clear on the point: Senator Ray's adviser, Senator Conroy, was on his feet only a short time ago saying that the caretaker convention meant that it was not desirable to announce significant projects, so that seems to be the only thing you are pointing to.
—Senator Alston, please speak to the chair and not across the chamber.

—If that is the case, then anything that Senator Faulkner might say by way of interjection is utterly irrelevant to that point. So, if the Labor Party is arguing that somehow it is improper to make announcements during the election campaign, why did he put out a release headed `$715,000 worth of grants announced for River Murray Corridor Green Projects' and saying, `The Federal Environment Minister'—we all know him: the minister for getting rolled—
—You know what the percentages are. This is a smear—you are smearing.
—Senator Cook, shouting in that fashion is totally disorderly. Persistent shouting is disorderly.
—He is smearing him, Madam President.
—Senator Cook, abide by the standing orders.
—It is a question of honesty.
—There is an appropriate time to take up and deal with answers. I call Senator Alston.
—Come on, boofhead.
—Senator Schacht, withdraw that remark.
—I do.
—As I was in the process of pointing out, `The Federal Environment Minister, Senator John Faulkner, today announced grants totalling $715,000 for community'—
—Why don't you just table it, boofhead?
—Senator Schacht, cease interjecting in that fashion.
—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Schacht should withdraw that remark. Rather than just stop interjecting, he ought to withdraw that remark. It was totally unparliamentary.
—Senator Schacht, I asked you to withdraw it previously and you did. You should withdraw it again. You should stand up when you withdraw.
—I do.
—All I can say is that it might get a few extra votes in Makin—in the preselection convention, I mean. It certainly will not get any in the electorate at large.
—How many attempts at preselection did you have? It was four or five—as many as Robert Hill.
—Order! Senators on my left are making far too much noise.

—Let us be quite clear as to what is being discussed here and what the thrust of the question is. Senator Faulkner seemed to be suggesting that there was something improper about announcing grants during the campaign period. I am simply pointing out, `The Federal Environment Minister today announced grants totalling $715,500'—I left out the 500, I think—

—Here you are: at the top it says `$715,000' and then in the second line it says `$715,500'—but, I suppose, what is an extra $500 when you are having fun? Here he was announcing grants for community vegetation corridor projects on 12 February 1996. So all I can say is that Senator Faulkner clearly accepts the proposition that there is nothing wrong with announcing projects if the decision has been taken prior to the calling of the election. Everyone else understands that. You can get up and rabbit on as much you like—or anyone can—to suggest that somehow this is in contravention of the arrangements that are in place. It clearly is not. The Labor Party knows it and so do we.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask again if the minister can explain to the Senate why 33 out of the 39 grants were in coalition seats, 12 of those in seats that were One Nation vulnerable, and two in the ACT, where Senator Reid was under challenge. Perhaps, Minister, you could also explain to the Senate how many of the 16 projects which did not make the 15-point threshold yet were selected by ministers were among the 39 grants which were announced by the government during the election campaign. If you do not know, take it on notice.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The proposition seems to be, once again, that there were certain grants that did not make the cut-off. This is a fundamental misunderstanding of the process. The bureaucrats gave us the full list—many hundreds of projects—and said, `At 15 points and above, there are 114. That is probably enough for you to choose from.' If it had been Senator Faulkner, you can rest assured he would have gone back and said, `Well, why didn't you just give me 60? Make it really easy and I can get on with doing some other things.' But, no, we did not take that advice; we looked at the best. We went right through the projects and chose the best. We were not concerned with the sort of numerical fun and games that Senator Faulkner might like to play; we were concerned to ensure that all those projects measured up—stacked up—against the proper criteria. We gave our reasons for doing that, and Senator Faulkner knows that because he sought to get access to them. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I ask that the document that the minister glanced at, which was obviously provided by the government advisers via the Government Whip to Senator Alston to try to help dig him out of the ditch, be tabled for the benefit of the Senate.

—Madam President, on the point of order: just so that Senator Faulkner is not taken by surprise, I did not actually glance at it at all. It was given to me because it is even further ammunition that refutes the claim he is making, and I may look at it in the next couple of minutes. I certainly have not looked at it at the present time and there is absolutely no basis for suggesting that any such document should be tabled.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Senator Ian Macdonald. Earlier this year the minister announced that the government was liaising with the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers, ASHRAE, to analyse cabin air quality on BAe146 aircraft. Is the minister aware that, internationally, Australia has proportionally the highest number of reported problems associated with oil fumes leaking into aircraft cabins and cockpits? Can the minister confirm that Ansett Australia have now withdrawn from the ASHRAE inquiry and, if they have, can the minister tell the Senate the reasons for their withdrawal?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I appreciate getting that question from Senator Woodley. It is a refreshing change to get a question from that side of the chamber that is sensible and shows some real interest in matters of public affairs. Senator Woodley has, as he mentioned, followed this along on a number of occasions. I, like Senator Woodley and many of my other colleagues from other parts of Australia, travel quite regularly from Brisbane to Canberra on the BAe and, of course, have a personal interest in ensuring that this aircraft is safe. Senator Woodley, as I have mentioned to you before, both CASA and BASI are continuing their investigations and are working with both Qantas and Ansett and their subsidiaries to get a better understanding of the issues. I and the government have absolute confidence in the work that both CASA and BASI do and in the investigations they are conducting. I am informed that CASA has ensured that a newly developed package of modifications is now available for the BAe146 operators so that they can improve their cabin environment. Certainly, the government will continue to ensure that both CASA and BASI take swift action to address problems that may arise.

answer.para: Senator Woodley, you asked a specific question, as I recall, about the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers. That organisation was doing some work, which I think we discussed previously when I answered a question. Senator Woodley, I am not publicly aware of the reason for that. It may have something to do with some legal obligations that, perhaps, it is better for me not to comment upon in the Senate. Senator Woodley, I am aware that you are chairing a Senate inquiry into the BAe146 and the problems with the cabin air. Perhaps it might be better if you put that question directly to Ansett in the course of your inquiries. They would be able to answer much better than I could why Ansett has withdrawn.

talk.start.para: —Can't you find out, Minister?
—If you listened, Senator Schacht—
—Senator Ian Macdonald, your remarks should be to the chair, not across the chamber.

—Thank you, Madam President. Senator Schacht has interjected and asked why I do not have an answer. The question asked, if Senator Schacht had listened, was whether I knew why Ansett had withdrawn from the inquiry. Of course, that is a matter specifically for Ansett. I have some information, but it is perhaps not appropriate to mention it publicly. But I am suggesting to Senator Woodley that he might put that question directly to Ansett during the course of the inquiry. Obviously, Senator Schacht has no interest or understanding of this matter, but that is typical of him and his colleagues. Senator Woodley, I suggest that is the best way out of it. I do thank you for raising this important issue.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Certainly I understand the sensitivity associated with this, but I am concerned about the government's responsibility in this area.
—Just fax it to Ansett.

—I am not asking Senator Schacht a question, so I do not need his answer. I am wondering whether the government is concerned about Ansett pulling out of the inquiry. Will the government ensure that Ansett will fulfil its corporate responsibility and duty of care towards passengers and crew and do they have any suggestions about how that might be done?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —In responding to Senator Woodley's supplementary question, Ansett and all other airlines in Australia will have to comply with any properly regulated requirements of CASA and any other federal government or other regulatory organisation. So if assessments are made then Ansett, along with every other airline, will of course comply. At this stage, Senator Woodley, CASA is monitoring the situation very closely, as I know you are. As I say, I hope that your committee can get the answer specifically to your question of why Ansett have withdrawn, but their withdrawal will not in any way impact upon the government's obligations and CASA's obligations to the flying public in Australia. If regulations are required, they will be introduced by CASA and all airlines will then comply.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Is the minister aware that it is a breach of proper process not to notify both successful and unsuccessful applicants for grants programs at the same time? Further, is he aware that applicants should be notified without unnecessary delay? Is he aware that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet provided advice to this effect to his department and to Environment Australia in the course of the election cam paign? Why did the minister ignore this advice? Why did he announce 32 of 60 projects during the election campaign, leaving the rest of the successful applicants and all of the unsuccessful applicants to be notified well after the campaign, on 15 October?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We were conscious of the caretaker conventions, and I think we have gone over that on a number of occasions. All of these projects were selected prior to the calling of the election and were then announced at a time of our choosing. That is what we did. There is a suggestion that somehow you should not announce things during a campaign. Let us remember the sorts of things that Labor did in 1996. It was not just $715,000; Senator Faulkner put out another press release promising to provide up to $25 million to the Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games. He then went on to announce that the Bureau of Environmental Economics would receive $2.8 million of new funding over four years. That was on 27 February. How long before the election was that?

answer.para: He announced $1.13 million, allocated over four years, to fund a major Labor government commitment to lead international efforts in the conservation of the albatross. There it is: it is on the record. You cannot have it both ways. If there were some projects that were ticked off before an election that were good news and that the voters might be interested in, you cannot say that somehow we should not announce them. Clearly that was not the approach Labor took three years ago. They chose to announce projects which, on the face of it, all seemed to be good news projects, so I cannot understand why they would be objecting to us announcing some good news projects. After all, those people who suffered for 13 years were looking for a bit of relief. They knew that they had a bunch of philistines running the show for all that length of time, and they were very interested in knowing whether there was going to be something in the area of cultural and heritage announcements. That is why we made the announcements we did—because we thought it was important that they be aware of them and they could take them into account if they chose. I very much doubt that these would have been huge vote swingers but, nonetheless, they were projects of importance, they were projects of significance and they were projects that deserved to be funded.

I think Senator Faulkner said there were 39 projects that went to Liberal seats. The fact is that 38 of the projects, or 64 per cent, were located in the 62 per cent of electorates held by the coalition, and 18 projects, or 30 per cent, were in the 33 per cent of seats held by Labor. Three projects, or five per cent, were in the five per cent of seats held by Independents, and one project went across multiple electorates. I would have thought that was a scrupulously fair allocation. It reflected the proportion of seats as held by the parties prior to the last election.

But that is a matter of interest to the political aficionados. It is really not the bottom line at all. The bottom line is whether these projects deserved to be supported, and that is where we have had this deadly silence from the Labor Party. They have not been prepared to single out one project. Go and ask Dick Adams in Lyons whether he objects to the Woolmers Heritage and Cultural Estate project on the Clarendon Homestead. talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the minister: isn't it true that 39 grants from the FCHP program were announced in the course of the last election? talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I think the honourable senator answered his own question in what he put in the second half of that question. —My question is to Senator Hill in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. When the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer, explained the coalition's victory on ABC TV on election night, he said:

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —All I can say is that I am pleased that the opposition recognises how well the economy is going and that it recognises what a good job this government is doing in relation to health, education, transport and the like—in other words, that there is not one single question that it is able to ask on the big issues before the nation today.

answer.para: Yes, we did make announcements under the Natural Heritage Trust during the last election. If Senator Cook would wish to reflect upon history, he will recognise in fact that the timing of the election was during the normal cycle when announcements are made under the Natural Heritage Trust. At this time of the year I am addressing the bids for Natural Heritage Trust grants, and in the next few months we will be making those announcements. This is one year on from the last election. So, yes, it was within the cycle, it was at the appropriate time, and this government was very pleased with those announcements under the Natural Heritage Trust.

I might say on that subject that, with regard to Bush Care alone—the revegetation of Australia—this year I expect to approve some 1,700 individual projects across Australia. This is a tremendous commitment by ordinary Australians through such organisations as Landcare to restore the health of the Australian environment. We are proud as a government that we set up the Natural Heritage Trust—$1.5 billion being reinvested in the environment of Australia—and we are proud of the fact that community groups are prepared, with the funding support of government, to lead on it and put in their own labour and their own efforts to help make a difference.

The Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program was somewhat similar. That was a $70.4 million project—part of the total $1 billion Federation Fund project—aimed to support communities in their support of historic and cultural assets with grants of up to about $5 million. We are pleased that, out of the 740 applications that we received, we were able to support 60 of those projects across Australia. We would have liked to have been able to support more, but there is not one single project that was not deserving of the funding it received. Interestingly, this Labor opposition has not been able to designate one single project that was not deserving of that support.

Yes, this government will use funding from time to time to support community projects, and it will do it properly. I invite Senator Cook to go through the 1,700 approvals that I will make this year in relation to Bush Care. I will invite him to see if he can find one that has been wrongly applied. We exercise this task with care, but we accept the responsibilities of ministers. That means that we do not always accept the officials' advice. We always take the officials' advice into account, but we make the decisions in accordance with the responsibilities we have, and we are proud of that.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that I am questioning him about unethical behaviour by the government at election time. Don't these announcements of over half a billion dollars constitute conclusive evidence not only that the government ignored the caretaker convention which states that `it is desirable, if the decisions concern significant initiatives, that they be announced in advance of the caretaker period in order to avoid controversy' but also that many of the projects announced were obviously and deliberately held back for announcement during the election campaign itself? With regard to your explanation about the appropriate time for announcement, does that mean that you have scant regard for your obligations under the caretaker conventions at election time? talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The caretaker convention does not say that if decisions have been made by a government in the lead-up to an election they should not be announced during the following month, or whatever is the period of that election.
—It says avoid doing so.

—Senator Cook is saying that the announcement should have been made earlier before the election. What I am saying to Senator Cook is that in the normal cycle the decisions were not made until shortly before the election. So in actual fact the announcements were made at the correct time, and Australians benefited from this government that is interested in supporting both our natural and cultural heritage in a way that is unprecedented. If, in 13 years of government, Labor had done more to support the natural, cultural and historical heritage of Australia, all Australians would be better off.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. May I say that this is a subject which is particularly relevant to this Senate at the moment, since the Senate has spent so much time on it. Will the minister inform the Senate of the environmental and economic benefits of the regional forest agreement that has been finalised for north-east Victoria?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for that important question. The North-East Regional Forest Agreement which has been signed by the Prime Minister and Premier Kennett is an excellent demonstration of this government's ability to produce excellent conservation outcomes while protecting jobs. The RFA, which covers an area of some 2.3 million hectares in north-eastern Victoria, will provide 20 years of security for the timber industry and, more importantly, 20 years of security for those 500 people who depend on that industry for their jobs.

answer.para: This government recognises the important role that the timber industry plays in regional Australia. In the north-east region, milling operations in towns like Mount Beauty, Mansfield, Myrtleford, Whitfield, Corryong and Benalla all play an essential role within the economic and social fabric of these communities. The RFA will maintain timber supplies at current levels and, with increased investment and value adding that will flow from the security of the agreement, both the Commonwealth and Victoria are confident that it will in fact help increase employment in the industry.

Through the Forest Industry Structural Adjustment Program and other arrangements that are being negotiated, we believe that this should also enable the mill in Mount Beauty to be secure. From an environmental perspective, the outcome in the north-east is outstanding—174,000 hectares will be added to the reserve system, which is an increase over the status quo of 42 per cent. The agreement will mean that just under 50 per cent of all public land within the region is preserved within the reserve system.

The agreement has, as far as practicable, achieved our national targets on public land. Of particular interest to many will be our decision to protect the Upper Wongungarra catchment, which will be added to the Alpine National Park. This is an area with high quality old-growth forest. Importantly, it will provide a protected habitat for the endangered spotted tree frog. The RFA also provides enhanced protection for other rare and threatened species. For example, the agreement establishes a 17,500 hectare special management zone to protect the habitat of the long-footed potoroo. Additions to the reserve system will also provide protected habitat for the powerful and sooty owls, the yellow bellied glider and the gang-gang cockatoo.

This is the third RFA signed in Victoria and the fifth nationally. As a result of those five RFAs, over 800,000 hectares has been added to the reserve system since the Howard government was elected in 1996—an outstanding result for Australian forests. Over the coming months we will be concluding RFAs for another six regions. By any measure, this government has stayed true to the intent of the National Forest Policy Statement negoti ated by the former Keating government—an initiative which we have been happy to acknowledge and to implement. The only thing missing in the equation is legislation which will further increase the security provided to those working in the timber industry, and that legislation is before the Senate at the moment. The issue now is whether the Labor Party is finally prepared to come on board and support what this government is doing in providing security for jobs and better environmental outcomes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his very informative answer. Some of us Victorian senators do go outside of our own suburbs. Will the minister inform the Senate whether the Victorian experience can be extended to the rest of Australia for the benefit of all Australians?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Certainly, as I was saying, we have further RFAs to be concluded in Victoria, in New South Wales and in Queensland. It really depends, in the two latter states, on the attitude of the state Labor governments, which has not always been helpful, and the attitude of the Commonwealth Labor opposition. The trouble is: federal Labor has already lost the support of its own traditional constituency.
—Madam President—

—Order! You can take a point of order, Senator Faulkner, but I should say the bill should not be being discussed at the present time. It is on the Notice Paper . So, Senator Hill, be careful not to intrude into that debate.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Can the minister finally put aside his bluster and take this opportunity to explain why he and his colleague Senator Hill chose to ignore nine of the 17 federation cultural and heritage projects which were rated by the two departments as very high, that is, with a score of 19 to 24 out of a maximum 24 points, and 70 of the 114 projects which were rated above the proposed 15-point threshold, in order to favour the 16 projects which were rated below the 15-point threshold?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —This is a classic example of the sort of question that you hoped you would not have to ask because time would have run out. Unfortunately, they have been caught short and, as a result, we are required to go over the same old ground. There was no such thing as a threshold. There was simply an arbitrary and gratuitous decision by the combined task force, presumably to try to alleviate the load of the decision makers by indicating that there were 114 projects that rated 15 points or more. It was being gently suggested that we might like to confine our attention to projects above the line. We were grateful for all of the point scores we got, but let it be perfectly clear that never at any stage was either department in the business of recommending or advising us on any particular project.
—Did you agree to those guidelines? You agreed to them.
—Senator Conroy, there is an appropriate time for you to ask questions and debate the matter.

—What we were required to do was to exercise our discretion and choose the best projects. The sad part is that the Labor Party's approach seems to be no, you do not have to extend yourself, you do not have to go and look at all those other projects. The safe and of course the lazy way out is simply to look at the top 114, probably to go back and complain about being given so many, when one had such a short concentration span.

answer.para: But we did not take the easy way out. We decided that we should examine all of those projects because those who took time to put them together deserve to have been properly considered. Of course, there were a lot from the other side of the chamber. It did not matter to those on the Labor Party side of the Senate because they were not particularly interested in any of these policy issue matters or the merits of arguments; they were simply interested in wondering how much more dirt they could dig up and use during the campaign. We were much more concerned to ensure that after 13 years of neglect we did come up with the best possible selection of 60 projects, cultural and heritage, and we did that. All I can say is that, if the Labor Party has any brains at all, they will keep Senator Carr well and truly hidden for the next 25 days. They will make sure that Senator Carr is nowhere to be seen because all he can do is cost Labor votes in any election whenever it might be held.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the minister to the minute to him from his department dated 20 August 1998, and ask: how can he claim that the department's actions were arbitrary and gratuitous? How can he claim that the department had said no 15-point threshold or benchmark, when the department's submission on which the ministers based their decision made it clear that the purpose of the submission was `to provide you with a list of highly rated . . . projects from which to select'? Is it not true that these highly rated projects are included in the submission as attachment B? Is it not also true that attachment B comprised only projects which rated 15 points or above? I repeat, Minister, how can you claim that there was no 15-point cut-off?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I was not talking about the actions of the department; I was saying that the decision to simply draw a line under 114 projects was not what we asked for. We asked for points assessments of all projects so that we could choose the most appropriate 60 projects, and that is what we did. The department might have thought they were being helpful, and we are not critical of that. As I say, they were probably brought up under the Labor government to think that, if you gave them any more than the bare minimum, they would be exhausted—they would not be able to focus, they would be wondering why they were being put upon to that extent. We were conscious of the need to give every project a fair scrutiny. That is what we did. The trouble seems to be that the Labor Party bitterly resents the fact that all 60 projects stand up.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked by Senators Collins, Conroy, Faulkner and Carr today, relating to the distribution of funds for the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects program.

After their departments had gone through a rigorous process of ranking projects, Senator Hill and Senator Alston, without departmental scrutiny, got together with a map of marginal seats and their own advisers and put the political fix in on these projects. They elevated 16 projects which ranked below the 15-point threshold to ensure that they had a range of potential announcements across marginal electorates and electorates which were vulnerable to One Nation. When members of the Liberal campaign committee, including Senator Alston and Senator Hill, detected slides in the coalition polling during the campaign, they would roll out a heritage announcement to give the local candidate a big hit in the media—a media bang with the taxpayers' buck; all contrary to our caretaker conventions.

But now we have two tables which starkly demonstrate and illustrate the fix that went in by the ministers. The first chart, this predominantly blue chart—blue for coalition seats—shows that 33 of the 39 grants were rolled out in the election campaign in an attempt to save coalition members from electoral oblivion. There are One Nation vulnerable seats here like Herbert, Maranoa, Wide Bay and, later on, Leichhardt. All seats which might have had a state One Nation member of parliament within their boundaries, or one directly adjacent, and were under threat got prompt attention. Senator Hill in particular, it seems, really fixed his attention on Bass to save his ministerial colleague Warwick Smith. Bass got three grants: one on 8 September and two on 16 December last year.

There are government marginals here like Leichhardt, Lilley, Macquarie, Deakin, Gilmore and Adelaide—all receiving special attention during the election campaign. How many Labor seats received a grant? I invite you to look at the red on the same table—Canberra and Fraser. Those particular grants were announced by Senator Reid because the polling showed that her Senate seat was under threat; it was being eroded by the Democrats. On that basis, you could say that 35 of the 39 announcements were made to see coalition members save their skins in the election. Senator Reid announced two Federation and Cultural Heritage Program projects in the ACT worth $1.15 million. She also announced $10.5 million worth of other federation grants—the National Centre for Christianity, plus the Federation Centre. And she helped turn the sod with John Howard for the National Museum. Senator Reid was very busy with heritage issues during the last election campaign.

After the election, in a global press release, Senator Hill and Senator Alston announced the leftovers. That is illustrated on a separate chart—again, Labor in red, coalition seats in blue and Independents in yellow. I invite you to look at the difference. In blue are the grants announced in the coalition seats in the election campaign, and in this chart are the grants announced after the campaign. This chart is top-heavy with Labor electorates. That is the difference. There are two in the seat of Sydney; there is one in Prospect; there is one in Reid; there are two in Perth. There is a joint project in Batman, Jagajaga and Scullin, which are three adjoining Labor seats. All in all, out of the 28 grants announced after the election, 14 were in Labor seats and three in Independent seats. The problem is that Senator Alston and Senator Hill have been caught out here. They are as guilty as hell of rorting this project. This is pork-barrelling, and Senator Hill and Senator Alston should come clean.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Faulkner, would you like to withdraw the allegation that people have rorted, please?

—I do not think that is unparliamentary. With respect, Madam Deputy President, I believe that Senator Hill and Senator Alston have rorted this process. I do not think it is unparliamentary, and I do not think I am required to withdraw. Unless you sought advice and persisted on that, I certainly would not withdraw. This is a fix, a rort, a pork-barrel, and I do not believe the word `rort' is unparliamentary in this context. I ask you to seek advice, and if you receive advice—
—I will seek advice and check what you have said.
—I make the serious point, Madam Deputy President, that I do not believe it is unparliamentary. It is a rort.
—I will seek advice.

—In question time this afternoon I listened in amazement to the tirade of abuse from the opposition concerning the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program. They have talked about dates for notification, numbers and colours in a desperate search to find this government's Ros Kelly memorial whiteboard. It is intriguing for us on this side of the chamber because this is the second time that the opposition have engaged in this desperate search. These people have a master's degree in pork-barrelling. Once again, they are trying to find justification for criticising this government's commendable efforts to make community based grants. They started with the Natural Heritage Trust. They insulted the Baillieu family and never apologised. They insulted my colleague Senator Winston Crane and his family and they never apologised. They never found a skerrick of evidence of a problem. And now they are at it again.

speech.para: The criteria and the process for the awarding of these grants are very clear. A total of 741 applications were received and the projects were evaluated by a task force made up of officers from DOCA and the department of the environment. The annoying part this afternoon concerning the announcement during the caretaker government period led me to glance at the media release put out by Senator Faulkner on 22 February 1996 during his dying days as minister for the environment. Interestingly, he talked about $1.3 million going towards the preservation of an albatross and the fact that albatrosses are a symbol of hope. There is an albatross hanging around the neck of Senator Faulkner. It is a dead albatross. It is called pork-barrelling and the Ros Kelly memorial whiteboard and long will it stay there. We know where the pork barrelling started. As I have said, Senator Faulkner and his colleagues have a master's degree in this subject.

Our projects, the federation projects, were evaluated against six very important criteria, the significance, the lasting nature, the appropriateness of them for the Centenary of Federation, the benefits to the broad community and partnerships and funding. I am very pleased to say that in my own state of South Australia some particularly commendable projects received funding. Among them are the Ayers House museum development and the Port Lincoln Civic Hall. Interestingly enough also, the Commonwealth railway museum received funding. I find that quite amusing. During their period in government the Labor Party managed to turn the entire Commonwealth railway system into a museum, so it is interesting that they should be grizzling about funding to adequately and appropriately conserve what is left of it. The Mawson collection, commemorating the incredibly brave expedition of Sir Douglas Mawson, also received funding. In South Australia $6.5 million worth of funding was allocated. I am very pleased to say that all of those communities were very happy with the allocation. How interesting it is that no-one on the opposition side has criticised one single project. There is nothing in there that they are prepared to criticise.

The facts about this issue are that the task force appointed gave a project score of four for each of the six criteria, leading to a score out of a total of 24. Ministers made their decisions using both sets of advice available to them, together with their own allocation, and projects were then selected for eligibility. It is a joke to sit in here during question time today and hear questions coming from the other side related to pork-barrelling and rorting of community grants when the searching and the trawling that went on through the Natural Heritage Trust and the trawling that is going on today have not turned up a single thing. Yet still they go on. I suppose the only thing we on this side of the chamber can do is take heart that there are no questions on the economy, because the economy is in very good shape. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Then Deputy Prime Minister, Tim Fischer, let the cat out of the bag on election night, when he told ABC television:

speech.para: Specific project announcements were always held back for announcement during the election campaign.

Never mind that that is grossly improper under the caretaker provisions that bind a government during an election campaign. Those provisions are there to make sure that governments do not use the public purse to buy their way into office. What did Tim Fischer say? He said:
Specific project announcements were . . . held back for announcement during the election campaign.

Tim Fischer is guilty on two fronts. The first is that he was being too honest. He was not supposed to blow John Howard's cover by doing that. He let the cat out of the bag. The second is that he is guilty of understatement. The total value of the projects announced during the election campaign was $557 million—over half a billion dollars that this government announced during the election campaign in order to buy their way back into elected office because they had the GST as an albatross around their neck. Let us be honest about this. That is what that was all about.

I am not saying that many of the projects that were announced are not worthy; obviously many are. But the timing of the government's announcement is unethical and is in conflict with the caretaker provisions. That is shonky, it has to be said, and the taxpayers in Australia do not expect their taxpayers' dollars to be purloined by a government to slip itself into office by announcing projects at an electorally sensitive time in order to buy votes. No taxpayer thinks that is a proper use of their dollar.

Let me give you a few examples, Madam Deputy President, of what I mean about the timing here. There was—no doubt a worthy project—$2 million for the Maroondah heritage estate in the city of Maroondah in Victoria. It was timed to help Mr Phillip Barresi, who holds the marginal seat of Deakin, where there was a margin of 2.5 per cent—very marginal in a GST election. Remember when I recite these dates that the election was on 3 October. When did Senator Alston announce the grant for the $2 million for the heritage estate in Mr Barresi's electorate? On 23 September, within the caretaker period, 10 days out from the election. That is when he announced it. Is that funny timing? Why did he have to announce it then, given that he announced all the losing bids after the election? Couldn't he have announced it then? Of course, in a marginal seat of 2.5 per cent it is to do with trying to influence the voters to vote for the coalition, overcome the GST.

It goes further. What did the city of Maroondah expect when it came to when this announcement would be made? They understood the announcement would be made in November. They got a hell of a shock when it was made before the election—on 23 September, 10 days before the election—because they were led to believe they were going to be told the outcome of their project application in November. Was this propitious timing or not? Let us see what then happened. Mr Phillip Barresi, who is the sitting member—with a 2.5 per cent margin, remember—got a supplement into the Maroondah Post, the local throwaway in his electorate, on 29 September, just a few days before the election itself. Fair enough, but, in order to have prepared the elaborate piece of publication and inserted it into the throwaway going into each home in that electorate, he must have known beforehand that this announcement was coming. If he did not, it was the slickest piece of publicity that anyone has ever seen. It strains credulity to believe that there was no foreknowledge in this case.

That is one example. There is another example, the Frankston community arts centre—again, no doubt, a worthy project in its own right. This relates to Mr Bruce Billson, the coalition marginal member for that seat. Mr Billson is sitting on a 3.4 per cent margin. Mr Billson is so well thought of by this government that they flew him to Adelaide to assist in the selection of the Natural Heritage Trust selections. He sat at the back of the room in order to aid the government—no doubt with his deep knowledge of marginal electorates. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —That was a valiant effort, Senator Cook. Who would have thought the Labor Party's stocks had dropped so low, both in this place and in the electorate, that this is the gravest issue that they can bring before the Senate today? Their stocks have dropped so low that Senator Faulkner has now reached the stage where he no longer knows what is parliamentary and what is not parliamentary, as in some of his appalling behaviour during question time today.
—I hope you are not reflecting upon another member.

—I am not reflecting on the member. I am only discussing the behaviour and the appalling stocks of the Labor Party, Madam Deputy President. speech.para: We have not had any questions from the Labor Party on those important issues—which every day Australians are interested in, because they mean jobs to them, income to them and a strong standard of living.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The Senate has proved its worth to the Australian people on many occasions, most recently with the Goods and Services Tax.
We need a strong and independent Senate to control the excesses of government, and to represent the 1 in 5 voters who have been effectively disenfranchised by the two-party system.

Our federal bicameral system of government consists of two separately constituted legislatures with equal power, each to act as a balance on the other, and to offer a degree of representation and accountability that is unachievable with a unicameral system.
The division of powers between the House of Representatives and the Senate helps to safeguard against the abuse of power by government.
A functional Senate is the best protection against the arbitrary exercise of power by the Federal Executive that we have.
Walter Bagehot, the famous English economist and journalist, issued the following warning in his book `The English Constitution':

`The most dangerous of all sinister interests is that of the executive government, because it is the most powerful. It is perfectly possible—it has happened, and will happen again—that the cabinet, being very powerful in the Commons, may inflict minor measures on the nation which the nation did not like, but which it did not understand enough to forbid. If, therefore, a tribunal of revision can be found in which the executive, though powerful, is less powerful, the government will be the better; the retarding chamber will impede minor instances of parliamentary tyranny'
This warning is as relevant to Australia in 1999, as it was to England in 1861.

As stated in Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, if a bad government possesses all powers, then all powers may be abused, but a strong Senate in a bicameral system acts as a safety mechanism against despotism, corruption, or ineptitude.

In order to offer the high level of representation and protection envisioned by the founders of the Constitution, it was necessary to constitute and elect each house by a separate distinctive process.
The Senate is elected by proportional representation, unlike the House of Representatives, in order to best reflect the diversity of electoral opinion in Australian.
The states are also guaranteed equal representation in the Senate, and this provides a crucial balance to the numerical advantage enjoyed by the more populous states in the House of Representatives.

Due to the rigid two-party system and compulsory preferential system in Australia, virtually all votes in the House of Representatives ultimately go to either the Labor party or the Coalition, and just 14 independents have managed to win seats in the House of Representatives since 1946.

This has resulted in the two-party domination and hegemony of parliamentary debate and economic and social policy in Australia, and the imposition on an unwilling electorate of all sorts of objectionable policies ranging from multiculturalism to National Competition Policy.
This is an unacceptable situation for the 20% of voters who voted for someone other than Labor or the Coalition in the House of Representatives in the 1998 federal election.

For these voters who have been effectively disenfranchised by the two party system, the Senate offers the only relief, where it is possible for independent candidates and small political parties to regularly get elected.

The operation of the Senate in fulfilling its constitutional role of countervailing government power and operating as a house of review has been the source of constant complaint from governments for many years, regardless whether Labor or the Coalition has been in power.
That the Senate fulfils its constitutional role very effectively is irrelevant to government politicians, who view it as a threat and maintain that the Senate `destabilises the political system'.
Yet when in opposition, these same politicians take full advantage of the operation of the Senate to further their own political goals.
The fact that the House of Representatives is dissatisfied with the powers and the conduct of the Senate at times is evidence in itself of the necessity of the Senate.

The easiest way for the government to obtain a majority in both the Senate and the House of Representatives is simply to get more votes buy enacting legislation that is more acceptable to the Australian people.
Methods to hamstring the Senate include replacing proportional representation with preferential voting, changing the number of senators representing each state, or imposing electoral thresholds.

In 1988, the Australian people wisely rejected a referendum to alter parliamentary terms so that all senators were elected at the same time. This would have increased the chance of one party or the other winning a senate majority.
This bill will preserve the current operation of the Senate by entrenching proportional representation as the method of electing the Senate.
As this is a constitutional amendment bill, it must be passed by an absolute majority in both houses of parliament.
It must then be put to the Australian people by referendum according to section 128 of the Constitution.
Item 1 of Schedule 1 of the bill will repeal the first paragraph of section 7 of the Constitution and substitute:

`The Senate shall be composed of Senators for each state, directly chosen by the people of the state, voting as one electorate, using a method of proportional representation that shall be uniform for all the states'.

Item 2 of Schedule 1 will repeal second paragraph of section 7, which will remove the ability of the Commonwealth to allow the Queensland Government to divide the state into divisions for the election of senators.

Items 3 and 4 of Schedule 1 add to end of section 122 of the Constitution: `subject to this section' and `A senator to represent such territory shall be directly chosen by the people of the territory voting as one electorate, using a method of proportional representation that shall be uniform for all such territories.'
The effect of items 3 and 4 is to ensure that a senator for any territory acquired by the Commonwealth will be elected in accordance with section 7 of the Constitution.

These changes, coupled with the requirement under section 24 of the constitution to maintain twice the number of House of Representative seats as Senators, will make it very difficult for a government to change the Senate status quo which has served us so well.
History has shown that as political power concentrates into fewer hands, accountability decreases, while bad policy and the potential for corruption increases.
John Stuart Mill said in his book, `Representative Government':

`The consideration which tells most, in my judgment, in favour of two Chambers (and this I do regard as of some moment) is the evil effect produced upon the mind of any holder of power, whether an individual or an assembly, by the consciousness of having only themselves to consult. It is important that no set of persons should, in great affairs, be able, even temporarily, to make their sic volo prevail without asking any one else for his consent. A majority in a single assembly, when it has assumed a permanent character—when composed of the same persons habitually acting together, and always assured of victory in their own House—easily becomes despotic and overweening'.
(Overweening means to be conceited or arrogant.)

The Australian people have by right of the Constitution the Senate as a second house of review, and it would be in their best interests to resist all attempts to nobble it, whether by cajolery or threat.

The necessity for a strong and effective house of review is now greater than ever due to the entrenchment of the two-party system in Australian politics and the increasing power and domination of the Executive over the legislature.
The latent danger for the Senate and the Australian people is that section 7 of the Constitution enables the government to fundamentally change the way the Senate functions without a referendum.

Evidently the founders of the constitution underestimated the determination of the two-party body politic to give themselves more power by neutralising the Senate under the guise of `providing stable government'.
Only with a referendum can the Australian people enshrine the Senate in its current form in our Constitution.
The referendum in November should be used to the defeat the republic, which will only give more power to the government.
A second referendum should also be put to the Australian people to preserve the Senate in its present form, which is the best way to keep the government honest and accountable.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
