subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Brown) agreed to:
That general business notion of motion No. 268 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate censures the Minister for Forestry and Conservation (Mr Tuckey) for inflaming rather than mitigating the conflict over Western Australia's Regional Forest Agreement.

This motion is a censure of the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, Mr Tuckey, because of his failure to mitigate the forest conflict, particularly in Western Australia, and in fact the way in which he has inflamed that conflict. I want to respond to Senator Ray, firstly, and say that I understand there have been similar censure motions before but, of course, it is logical that the Senate must be in a position to be able to censure an aberrant minister in the House of Representatives, where the government has the numbers to prevent any censure being put forward if the circumstances arise. That is part of the fundamental independence of the two houses.

Let me assure Senator Ray that I do not raise this matter lightly or frivolously. It is a very serious matter and, as a conservationist, I find it particularly serious that this minister has not fulfilled at all his portfolio responsibilities for conservation, let alone conservation of forests. In fact, in every move, every statement and every action he has made since that appointment by the Prime Minister, he has vilified conservationists. He has added to the unpopular moves to put the Australian forests in line for further destruction and he has also, I believe, deceived the very people he purports to support—that is, the workers in the industry.

And there I come back to my final submission in the earlier debate. Since the regional forest agreement, which was touted to make safe the jobs of those in the industry, was signed in Tasmania, 480 jobs have been lost in the industry. Since woodchipping arrived in Australia in 1969, which has seen 20,000 jobs lost out of the industry, the whole process has been not only kept up in the wake of the regional forest agreements but accelerated. Mr Tuckey has done nothing about that. In fact, he supports regional forest agreement legislation which does nothing at all to protect or compensate workers in their jobs or workers who lose their jobs. In fact, what he has helped to bring before this parliament is a bill containing a massive compensation clause for the real victors in this process—that is, the giant woodchip companies. Under section 7 of that legislation, with this minister's support, they would be given multimillion dollar compensation from the taxpayers of Australia, through the federal government, if in some future case they are denied access to the wild forests of Australia because the public demanded and sought federal action to protect those forests.

I predict that that is going to happen. The regional forest agreement that Wilson Tuckey, the minister, has become the chief advocate for is a prescription for broadscale destruction of forests from Western Australia through to Victoria, Tasmania and New South Wales and extending into south-east Queensland. But the Australian people are not going to stand for it. The opinion polls repeatedly show that the vast majority of Australians out there—be they Liberal, National Party, One Nation, Green, Democrat or Labor supporters—are opposed to the continued destruction of our wild forests.

I ask all senators to look at those figures, because that is the feeling we should be representing. Minister Tuckey had the opportunity to usher in a win-win situation where those forests would be protected. This parliament has the power and the ability to give transitional funding to the enormous plantation base which can supply all of Australia's forest needs and which, with downstream processing, could have created, and should be creating, thousands of jobs. Instead of that, he has gone for the failed past prescription of keeping the big woodchip corporations in the jarrah and karri forests, in the world heritage value forests of Tasmania and in the rainforests.

Mr Acting Deputy President Ferguson, you should see the massive pile of rainforest woodchips now on the Burnie wharf. For a quick profit, these ancient ecosystems are ready to be transported to the Japanese pulp and paper mills in the coming months. That is beside the enormous pile of eucalyptus woodchips on the same wharf. It is an override of an earlier move by Burnie City Council not to expand that wharf. Now they are going for a third pile of woodchips in this age of regional forest agreements—a la Minister Wilson Tuckey—which not only does not lead to a wind-down of this destruction but leads to wholesale slaughter and puts the forests at the behest of those sitting in the boardrooms of a few big woodchip corporations.

With them go the jobs. Woodchipping is not a job creator; it is a job destroyer. I feel sorry for the Forest Protection Society, which sides with the woodchip corporations and with Minister Wilson Tuckey in this process. I understand that, in recent times, of those 480 jobs lost in Tasmania 40 were out of the industry that transports the logs to the ports of Tasmania and to the woodchip mills. More than 30 of those were cardholders for the Forest Protection Society. What do they get from this society—this front for the woodchip corporations—for their adherence to it, for turning up at protest meetings and for their vilification of conservationists?

talk.start.para: —What do your people get? The dole!

—Senator Abetz supports this: they got the sack. Worse than that, these people have very big investments in the machinery which they thought would be sustained. They were promised that the regional forest agreements would make their jobs safe. When they go to the wall, the bailiff moves in and their houses go as well.
—You would do that to all of them.

—Senator Abetz interjects. In the Tasmanian parliament 15 years ago I moved to have legislation making the woodchip corporations underwrite these contracts for these cartage contractors and people in the forests, but neither Labor in Tasmania nor the Liberals have ever done that, because they would end up being the lackeys of the big woodchip corporations. It is not in their interest to underwrite anybody, least of all the workers. They know that their profit line is enhanced by getting rid of the workers, and that is why I am disgusted with the behaviour of this minister. He is not a conservationist—he has never purported to be one; the Prime Minister knows he is not—and he is in favour of destruction of the forests. As minister for forestry, he purports to be a supporter of jobs in the industry, and so does Prime Minister Howard, but everywhere that they sign these regional forest agreements the job slaughter goes on.
—Ha!

—Senator Abetz laughs at that, but it is no laughing matter for those people in Tasmania who have gone to the wall and who have been fooled, deceived and let down by this disgusting regional forest agreement process now overseen by this failed minister. Worse than that—and that is the reason behind this censure motion—this minister has deliberately inflamed the situation. He accepted an iron bar gift from loggers. I do not know whether these logger vigilantes were there on the acceptance podium with him just a couple of weeks ago. This is a symbol of violence from this minister, who should stand for peace and creativity in the forests. He is a man who talked about war in the forests in Western Australia when he should have been talking about peace. He is a man who said that costs should be reclaimed from the arrested conservationists who had been behaving in an allegedly illegal way, but he has not called for a cost restitution from the thugs, some of whom I daresay he has rubbed shoulders with when they went into the bush—the peaceful bush—on the weekend to beat up and intimi date citizens simply because they had a different point of view and had the guts to be out there in the forest peacefully defending it.

speech.para: That is the behaviour that leads to a police state. That is the behaviour that pulls the rug from under democratic norms. That is the behaviour of violence. That is the behaviour of failure, not of success. This minister deserves censuring. He has not got an apologetic bone in his body. Maybe that is part of politics, but we should be able to expect sense from him. We should be able to expect a move for a win-win situation, and we should be able to expect him to carry out the responsibilities of his portfolios.

Minister Tuckey says he speaks frequently with the Prime Minister. I would like to know how much Prime Minister John Howard has goaded him into the destructive attitude he has taken in an already volatile situation in Western Australia, let alone around the rest of the country. It is time for the Prime Minister, if he is dinkum in wanting that portfolio to stand for both forestry and conservation, to put an end to this failed ministry—this destructive and inflammatory ministry. It is time for the Prime Minister to carpet Wilson Tuckey and tell him he is sacked.

The least he could do is bring him in and tell him he is responsible for the division that is boiling in Western Australia because the majority of people right across the political spectrum are having their aspirations for the future of forest heritage in that state denied them by the political process. What a remarkable situation it is when the Court government itself responds to that public feeling and Wilson Tuckey then fights that government's democratic response. What an extraordinary situation that is.

The Prime Minister, of course, is involved right up to his neck in Wilson Tuckey's actions. He appointed this man knowing his record and knowing that he is no fixer. He is a destroyer not only of forests but also of the public wish to reach a win-win situation, which is available. A minister who fails as comprehensively as that deserves to be censured. I do not move this motion lightly. I do not take it frivolously. This is a serious situation in our country which should never have occurred. Certainly the events of last weekend would not have occurred, I believe, if Minister Tuckey had been acting according to the demands of the very pivotal ministry he has on this vexed issue. He deserves censure. I believe he deserves dismissal. The Prime Minister should be the one acting here, not the Senate.

I believe the Senate has a very heavy responsibility here. I hear what Senator Ray says. We cannot bring forward motions like this frivolously or because we have a bee in our bonnet or because we happen to take a different point of view. It is a serious matter. We have a seriously failed minister here and I am fearful about him staying in that portfolio. I am fearful that what happened last weekend could get worse. I am fearful that this minister, instead of pouring oil on the troubled waters, is simply going to put another match to the whole situation. It is not good enough. It is time to call him in. It is time at least for this Senate to give him a censure.

talk.start.para: —This Tasmanian Green sponsored censure motion should win the gold medal for double standards but fail to qualify for its repetition of mindless inaccurate assertions. Indeed, what we heard today from Senator Brown is, I would have thought, a most inflammatory speech. Why doesn't the honourable senator take his own medicine and try to calm the situation down a bit? He is not interested in doing that because he somehow thinks that his political lifeblood is associated with inflaming environmental issues in trying to desperately grasp for votes. Indeed, in recent times, the Greens have seen political demise in his home state of Tasmania. As a result of his former leadership of the Greens, they now have one Green in the Tasmanian parliament and in this parliament there is, of course, now only Senator Brown left.

speech.para: The mover of the motion has in fact gained for himself a reputation for divisiveness, inciting violence and damage to persons and property unparalleled in recent times. The mover of this motion is the one and same person who presided over a demonstration in my and his home state of Tasmania when the regional forest agreement was signed and where $6,000 worth of damage was done to the car in which the Prime Minister was travelling and clothing and uniforms were wrecked. Did Senator Brown come into this chamber rubbing his hands and being concerned about that sort of violence and that sort of inflammatory behaviour? No, because he was at the heart of it. Because he was at the heart of it, it is somehow okay despite the damage to a vehicle and property. Of course, we all recall the shameful behaviour at a demonstration in Tasmania—in which Senator Brown took part—where the Prime Minister's wife was jostled.

I would have thought that sort of behaviour would be abhorrent to any decent thinking Australian. Indeed, it is therefore quite duplicitous for somebody with such a record to come into this chamber feigning his concern about somebody inflaming a situation when he himself has been involved in conduct a lot worse—being at the forefront of damage to people's property and being at the forefront when the Prime Minister's wife was jostled. The credibility of the mover of this motion is zilch—nil. There is no credibility whatsoever.

Now, with breathtaking audacity, he moves this censure motion, asserting falsely that the popular Minister for Forestry and Conservation inflamed the conflict in Western Australia over the sensible regional forest agreement in that state. Let me stress at the outset that we on this side have complete confidence in our Minister for Forestry and Conservation, the Hon. Wilson Tuckey MP. I invite the Democrat and Independent senators to consider the deficient state of the evidence put before this Senate by Senator Brown and to reject the motion. In considering the paucity of the evidence, they might consider the overwhelming evidence on the other side of the debate—as so articulately put in a Department of Conservation and Land Management information bulletin dated 23 August 1999, signed off by Neil Burrows. It says:

If, like me, you thought that anti-logging protesters were gentle, passive people who were trying to save the forests, then you're wrong. There is an extreme element in the "green" movement, which is violent, aggressive, and which is lashing out at a society they do not want to be part of. They will use any controversial issue, including the forest debate, to vent their anger at society.

Late on Friday afternoon last week, I was working in my office at CALM when a group of about 25 banner waving, chanting protesters burst through a door to my office which opens to the outside of the building, but is not the public access to the building. I asked them to leave my office and tried to block them from moving into the main building. I was overwhelmed by sheer weight of numbers. Then I was set upon by one of the group who attacked me with fists flailing. I attempted to fend off the blows but was struck on the side of the head and in the throat.
Did Wilson Tuckey occasion this? Did he inflame this? Or was it the greens and people like Senator Brown who inflamed this sort of violent behaviour?

If the Democrats and Independents in this place want to be in the game of censoring people, they ought to seriously consider—if that is what they believe—the alleged faults on both sides, because it would be disingenuous, indeed dishonest, of the Senate to seek to lay blame on only one side when the people who are undoubtedly the supporters of the green movement behave in such an outrageous way. The bulletin continues:
The group shouted abuse and questions at me and howled me down whenever I tried to respond.
He went on to say:
My grandfather and my great uncles did not put their lives on the line in two world wars for a society that resolves internal issues by mob violence.

I invite Independent senators and Democrats senators to consider the credibility of voting on this motion without taking into account that this sort of conflict within the community usually involves two sides. Are we really saying that the honourable minister is responsible for the greens' physical attack on an innocent public servant going about his job? Of course he is not. Who is responsible? Undoubtedly elements within the green movement which orchestrated that event—that violent event where fists were thrown and somebody was punched on the side of the head and in the throat—are responsible.

So I say to the Democrats and Independent senators in particular: your own credibility within the community will be enhanced if you have got the courage to say, on this occasion in particular, that you could not vote for this motion on the basis of the paucity of the evidence and the clear physical violence perpetrated by others on the other side of this debate. I suggest to you, and Senator Ray I think hinted at it in relation to previous censure motions in this place: if you keep moving censure motions willy-nilly against a minister on trumped up charges, you will have a complete demeaning of the currency of censure motions in this place; indeed, they will be laughed at.

It is for the Democrats and the Independents to consider whether or not they want to be part and parcel of this demeaning process of censure motions within this place or whether they will take a stand. Indeed, I would invite them to even potentially abstain, on the basis that I fully understand that they do draw on a green constituency and, on the odd occasion, they think it may be somehow politically beneficial to them to be seen to vote for a censure of the minister. But I say to them in all seriousness: your long-term prospects will not be served by engaging in this grubby little exercise.

I would have thought that, especially amongst Democrats voters, a simple explanation—Senator Brown moved this motion—would be sufficient justification for saying that was the reason you did not vote for it. I notice Senator Greig with a smile on his face, and I am sure that his West Australian colleague, Senator Murray, would appreciate that, because Senator Murray has spoken very eloquently on this stunt.

Senator Brown addressed this issue with all the emotion and passion with which he addressed the issue of whether or not we ought to be forced to wear jackets in this chamber. We are sick and tired of hearing the same sort of emotional claptrap from a senator for whom every issue becomes a major issue.

In inviting the Democrats and Independents to consider their stance, I suggest to the Australian Labor Party senators—in particular Tasmanian Labor Party senators—that they think very carefully about supporting a motion, sponsored by Senator Brown, which, if you do not read the words of the motion but rather listen to the speech, is a condemnation of the regional forest agreement within his own home state of Tasmania, which the state Labor Party fully supports. Indeed, the Labor Party in Tasmania fully supports our federal legislation.

The Labor Party members of this federal parliament who come from Tasmania are really stuck between a rock and a hard place. They know what the people of Tasmania want. The people of Tasmania want the regional forest agreement process because it is good for jobs, it is good for the environment, and it provides some job stability. The regional forest agreement in my home state, which Senator Brown has sought to condemn, put another 400,000 hectares into reserves, which means that 40 per cent of the land mass of Tasmania is in reserves. Tell me any other state—indeed, any other nation in the world—that has a similar figure. There is not one that can be alluded to or referred to, even with Senator Brown still in the chamber.

It is the most comprehensive anywhere in the world. Yet Senator Brown and the extreme Greens demand more and more to be locked up. Every time you lock up another hectare it means a loss of jobs. What the federal government has done with the regional forest agreements right around this country is to balance up jobs and conservation on a scientific and reasonable basis to ensure that both can live together in harmony. I wonder sometimes whether or not the Greens believe that human beings are part of nature. Part of the wonderful natural process, for example, is that from time to time beavers chop down trees and dam rivers. When beavers do it, it is wonderful because they are part of nature; if human beings were to do it, it would be rampant environmental disaster. I can just hear Senator Brown saying, `It will be the last living tree on earth that we cut down'—and all the other rhetoric.

What are we as humans actually allowed to do in this world in relation to natural resources? If Senator Brown had his way, would he allow one tree to be chopped down, one mine to be opened, one river to be dammed? The answer is no to each of those questions. He has opposed in this place, and previously in the Tasmanian parliament, every single development which might create jobs. Indeed, he talks about woodchipping in my home state of Tasmania. I simply say to Senator Brown and to those who may have listened to his rather inept contribution: why would anybody want to sell timber for woodchips when they can command a higher price by selling it for saw log? It makes no economic sense. Even if they are purely motivated by greed and nothing else, surely greed itself would determine that you would sell that timber for saw log rather than woodchip. Why would you sell a log for woodchips and get, say, $10 instead of $100 for saw logs? There is no explanation and, of course, that is what blows Senator Brown right out of the water. When you consider the mantra that Senator Brown comes out with, it does not bear any analysis whatsoever.

The loss of jobs in my home state of Tasmania can be put down to a number of activities by the Greens. The loss of power station developments, the loss of Wesley Vale and the ongoing campaigns to stop good, sound forestry practices are all part and parcel of the Greens' activities which result every day in the loss of jobs. Then when the federal and state governments come together to put an agreement into place for job security, Senator Brown is out there seeking to condemn it. I remember a recent debate in this chamber when Senator Brown—or one of his Greens (WA) colleagues—was seeking to congratulate Holland or the Netherlands for no longer sourcing certain timbers out of the jarrah forests of Western Australia, allegedly because that country was concerned about our environmental record. That was pretty good, emotive stuff and pretty hard to argue against, until you do a bit of research.

Where was the Netherlands then sourcing their timber needs from? Ghana, from Africa. I ask you: does anyone in this chamber honestly believe that in a Third World African country such as Ghana they have a forest practices code anything equivalent to what we have in this country? Absolutely not. So the loss of that contract to Western Australia meant the rape of forests in Africa where there is no forest code. Isn't it the Greens who tell us to `think globally, act locally'? What Senator Brown did on that occasion, along with the Greens, was to think locally and say, `Look after my few trees, but let them rape the forests in Africa.'

In denying the Wesley Vale pulp mill in my home state of Tasmania, he guaranteed the longevity of a polluting mill in Japan, pouring out worse pollution than any mill that would have been sited at Wesley Vale and ensuring that we would not value add our timber within this country. So he comes to this debate with a record of opposition to absolutely anything and everything that would be of assistance to this country in seeking to reverse—and this is an interesting figure—the annual $2 billion deficit in wood and paper products.

Most Australians do not realise that Australia imports $2 billion worth more of timber and paper products than it exports. Where do you think all the extra wood and paper products come from? They come from the South-East Asian forests, from the African forests and from the South American forests—from countries which have absolutely no forest codes in place. Where is the environmental sense in trying to close down our industries when we know full well the source of the much needed timber and paper is going to come from those poorer Third World countries whose environments are being absolutely ravaged and destroyed?

Indeed, Senator Brown and the Greens could do something sensible for this country and promote timber and paper products sourced from our forests on the basis that we have world-class forest codes in place, second to none in the world, and that we are concerned about replanting and regenerating our forests. The minister, Wilson Tuckey, knows that as Minister for Forestry and Conservation, if he did not look after the forests—the conservation and the replanting—there would be no forestry industry left within this country. So the minister is very mindful of that.

I come back to the motion before us. It is an unsustainable assertion that Mr Tuckey allegedly inflamed the situation over the Western Australian Regional Forest Agree ment. I would be interested to hear the views of others in this debate as to what condemnation we ought to be referring to in relation to the Greens that attacked this one lonely, peace-loving public servant. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The last few words by Senator Abetz demonstrate just how shallow his argument has been this afternoon in trying to defend the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, Mr Wilson Tuckey. To call him a peace loving public servant would have to be either the height of hypocrisy—
—I was talking about Neil Burrows—

—I understood you were also referring to this so-called wonderful minister. There is no way that the actions of Mr Tuckey, since he assumed the role of minister, can be defended. We are, once again, having an emotional debate in this chamber on the forestry issue. It is a pity we are not devoting the time of the Senate to debating the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 . The government has had this major piece of legislation on the table since last year and on the Senate's Notice Paper since the beginning of this year. Minister Tuckey was appointed to have carriage of this primary piece of legislation. He was to get it through this parliament to enable the regional forest agreement process to be completed by its due date—that is, the end of this year. This is the piece of legislation that Minister Tuckey has allowed to sit and languish in the parliament. We are now getting towards the end of August and are yet to consider the bill at the committee stage.

speech.para: This is the bill that this government and this minister said was so important that it had to be debated and passed by the Senate within the first week of parliamentary sittings in February this year. It is an absolute disgrace—and clearly a dereliction of duty by Minister Tuckey—that we are now at the end of August and have yet to even get to the committee stage of considering this important piece of legislation. The reason for this is that Minister Tuckey is incompetent. That is not just the view of the Labor Party and it is not just the view of Senator Brown, whose views on the forestry debate, I have to say, we have not agreed with that often. Certainly, one thing that all of the players—and, increasingly, industry representatives—have agreed is that Mr Tuckey is incompetent.

Let us have a look at his record. He was put in charge specifically to look after forestry and conservation issues, which had previously been under the charge of Minister Anderson. He was hand-picked by the Prime Minister and had the primary task of getting the RFA legislation through the parliament and having agreements reached in the nine RFA areas by the end of this year. When he took over the ministry, three RFAs had already been negotiated. Up until two months ago, there were still only three RFAs negotiated. The minister had been in his ministerial position for at least eight months with one task and one task only—to finalise RFAs around this country—and he had not done so. He then announced, in a big fanfare, that an agreement had finally been negotiated in Western Australia. This was something we had been waiting for for months. Within two weeks, the Western Australian government—his own coalition colleagues—walked away from that RFA at a million miles an hour. Mr Tuckey's first RFA in Western Australia since he became minister was thrown out within two weeks. What was Mr Wilson Tuckey's response? He was somewhere in Helsinki at the time. He was quoted as saying on the PM program:

I got preliminary advice from other sources and, in fact, I have spent three hours on the phone. I got up at 3 o'clock in the morning in Helsinki to talk to people at the appropriate time here. As I told them, if you proceed with this—I quoted some words from Phantom of the Opera —`There will be war between us', and that is where I stand on it.

Those were Wilson Tuckey's words in respect of his attitude to his own coalition colleagues in the Western Australian government over the Western Australian RFA. He said, `There will be war between us!' We all know that Mr Tuckey is prone to colourful language and is prone to bluff and bluster. In fact, he is not just prone to it; he knows no other way of expressing his views. Throughout his tenure as minister, he has constantly used inflammatory language and made speeches in which he has attacked various groups involved in the forestry debate and abused them for holding their particular points of view.

It is one thing for Senator Abetz to stand here and try to apportion blame to other groups. I have to say that in this debate there have been inflammatory views expressed time and time again from all sides of the debate, because views are passionately held. We saw no greater evidence of that than back in 1995, with the blockade of this parliament. It was to try to bring about some balance and some commonsense into the debate that the Labor government pursued the development of the national forest policy statement and subsequently the RFA. But it is totally wrong for a minister charged with the responsibility of bringing about rational agreements in this industry to resort to the sort of language that he has used, of declaring war upon state governments.

That was not the only time he did it. I attended a conference earlier this year, the `Outlook 99' conference of ABARE here in Canberra. Minister Tuckey was one of the speakers and I was in the audience that day. He stood up and he stated to the audience there—an audience no doubt mainly of industry representatives, so he would have felt that he was at home talking to them—that in his view the 60 per cent figure for the protection of old-growth native forests in the JANIS criteria was never a minimum, but was only a target. What that meant was that he was not committed to the criteria that had been developed for even the protection of the minimum level of old-growth native forests throughout Australia, let alone pursuing those other objectives which are about, over time, moving to a plantation based industry and looking further into reducing our reliance upon old-growth native forests and other native forests to sustain the timber industry. He was not interested in a balanced view. His view was that 60 per cent was just a figure that, whilst it may have been in the national forest policy statement and in the agreed criteria, as far as he was concerned was irrelevant. The clear message was that he was not about to worry too much about protecting all that much native old-growth forest at all.

Minister Tuckey is losing support, quite clearly, amongst his own coalition colleagues throughout the country, as evidenced by the reaction from the Western Australian government. He is also losing support on the ground within the timber industry. His continual attacks on the New South Wales government over its record on conservation are the height of hypocrisy. The New South Wales Labor government has done more to protect and develop the national parks and the national forest estate of this country than any other government.

Wilson Tuckey's approach has been that, because it is a Labor government, he will play politics: he will deny funding under the programs for structural adjustment and other funding available to people in the timber industry. He has attacked timber industry representatives on the north coast because they dared to sit down and negotiate agreements with the New South Wales Labor government. He condemned the New South Wales government even though his own coalition colleagues in the upper house in New South Wales supported the very legislation put through by the New South Wales Labor government.

The problem we have with Mr Tuckey is that he is a loose cannon. He is exploding all over the place, attacking his coalition colleagues in Western Australia, attacking industry representatives, attacking the conservation groups. We obviously expect that he will attack us from time to time. It appears that there is no-one safe from Minister Tuckey's outrage and inflammatory approach to this issue. Of course, it is on the record that he was there the other day, clearly geeing up people in Western Australia to raise the temperature of the debate over there.

One has to ask why the Prime Minister persists with this minister. As I said, we are now near the end of August and we have not even got to the start of debating this legislation in the committee stage. It is important legislation. We have something like three or four months left in which to see the remaining four—probably five if you include the Western Australian RFA—still to be finalised and negotiated by the end of this year. On this minister's current track record, it will be four or five years before he ever gets around to doing it, not four or five months. We all know that, if those RFAs are not negotiated and in place by the end of this year, real problems will eventuate. This is because of the fact that the permission for export licences is removed in non-RFA areas at the end of this year. Mr Tuckey's job is to get those RFAs negotiated, and to get them negotiated in keeping with the principles of the national forest policy statement.

I understand that we are not able to debate the legislation that is on the Notice Paper—we may get to it some time later today or this week—but I cannot help but remark that we have put up quite a large number of amendments which will improve that legislation. We are hopeful that this Senate will see its way clear to passing those amendments that will improve the legislation, that will see a better outcome with respect to RFAs, that will enable the situations that have developed in Western Australia to be avoided by having some degree of Commonwealth scrutiny over the agreements.

But what has Minister Tuckey's announcement been? And, indeed, I put the Prime Minister in this particular category. What has his response been to the possibility that those amendments might be carried by the Senate? He said that he will withdraw the legislation. He will just withdraw it. He will walk away. He will take his chainsaw and go home. Typical Wilson Tuckey approach.

talk.start.para: —Order! `Minister Tuckey', thank you.

—Minister Tuckey. This is a process that has been carefully constructed and put together in a very hot atmosphere over the past six or seven years. All parties in the political spectrum recognise that this is not an easy situation to resolve, and that there are strongly held views on the pro-conservation side and on the industry side. But Minister Tuckey's approach is that, if he does not get his way, then he will tear up the entire script and walk away. What sort of an attitude is that from a minister charged with trying to bring about stability, resource security and preservation of conservation values into the next millennium in the forest industry and in the forests of this country?

speech.para: It is incompatible with the responsibilities of a minister of the federal government to be going around the country inciting people, declaring war upon state governments, making outrageous allegations about anybody who disagrees with him and tearing up the national forest policy statement. The industry and the future of Australia's forests, if they are left in the hands of this minister, are in dire jeopardy. Whether or not this Senate sees fit to censure the minister is not really the point at the end of the day. The point is this: the Prime Minister should sack Mr Tuckey and he should sack him now.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this motion before us. Senator Forshaw did not inform us whether they were voting for the motion or against it, because he did not talk about the motion—and nor did Senator Brown. It is very noticeable that Senator Brown in his contribution never mentioned Mr Burrows, the CALM officer. He appears to be applying one set of rules on one side of the debate—which is fairly normal—and another set of rules in another circumstance. I find that very regrettable, because the motion says:

speech.para: That the Senate censures the Minister for Forestry and Conservation (Mr Tuckey) for inflaming rather than mitigating the conflict over Western Australia's Regional Forest Agreement.

In an earlier contribution, when we were discussing whether or not we would debate this motion, Senator Ray said words to this effect: `I am here to listen to the case'—and it is unfortunate that Senator Ray is not here—`as to whether or not there is a censure to bring against Mr Tuckey with regard to the mitigating of the conflict over the Western Australian Regional Forest Agreement.'

talk.start.para: —I am here listening to you.

—I notice you are here and I acknowledge that. There are a number of points I would like to make at the very beginning of this, and I will back this up with information. The first point that I would make is: Mr Tuckey has never condoned acts of violence.
—What about his iron bar?
—We are talking about a motion before the chamber right now. That is what I am talking about now.
—His iron bar is the issue.
—Order! Senator Crane has the floor.

—Mr Tuckey has never said that violence is the way to resolve the issues as far as the RFA is concerned. He actually warned the authorities that this might happen. On the other hand, we could compare that with the behaviour when there was a protest here some time ago. You will remember that Mr Beazley addressed a number of representatives from the union movement here. What happened at the end of that? They attacked this building. They tore a shop to pieces and they seriously injured a policewoman. I find that extraordinary when you compare the behaviour in that particular instance with what is happening now.

speech.para: If we want to talk about war, let us get the actual facts of the case right. I put on the public record right here now that it was Donna Selby, Messrs Glauser and Robertson's mate from the WA conservation movement, who clearly stated at the signing of the RFA, while being ejected by the police, that the signing meant war in the forests. This was repeated on the TV news that evening on a number of occasions. That is where the original quote in terms of war came from.

We have heard from Senator Abetz, with regard to the letter from the CALM manager, on violence by the greenies. That spells out quite clearly what the situation was there and that the law should be applied to everyone equally. I make this particular point in dealing with this motion before us because I recall an event of some years ago. I am sure people on the other side of this chamber, particularly the Labor Party, would remember this. A particular stalwart of theirs called Jack Marks, with others, had fishing shacks between Lancelin and Dongara on the west coast north of Perth. What happened? The authorities sent in the bulldozers and removed those fishing shacks.

We have had in much of our forests interference with legal operations for a significant period of time. We have heard from Minister Edwardes in the Western Australian government that she is trying to negotiate her way through this and we have heard from others. We have had direct defiance, with individuals lying in front of bulldozers and mucking around with the process. In my view, they have been breaking the law. Yet there was no mention of that in the contribution from Senator Brown. Nor was there any mention of that in the contribution from Senator Forshaw. If it is good enough for the people who had their fishing shacks on the west coast to be treated in that manner and to have them removed and have to comply with the authorities, then it is good enough for the people who occupy the forests and interfere with the legitimate processes there.

I go now to the substance of what I have termed—and these are my words—`the best of the West'. No doubt the West Australian have trawled through every article they could find. I think it would be fair to say that they are no friend of Wilson Tuckey's in this debate—in fact, they have taken a particular line. This is what they list as the best quotes from Mr Tuckey:
Federal Forestry Minister Wilson Tuckey has been accused of inflaming tensions in the forest debate. Here are some of his comments:
. There could be anarchy in the forests if protesting greenies are not removed. August 19
. WA Environment Minister Cheryl Edwardes has a history of turning every portfolio she administers into a disaster and her forest stewardship was on the same track. August 11
. Premier Richard Court had started a war with the Federal Government by backing out of the Regional Forest Agreement. It would not end until the agreement was reinstated.
. Welcomes police move to claim costs from forest protesters on behalf of logging contractors. June 8
I would hardly use any of those quotes I call `the best of the West ' as a reason for a condemnation of Minister Tuckey in the words of this motion, which says:
. . . for inflaming rather than mitigating the conflict over Western Australia's Regional Forest Agreement.
In fact, they are pretty mild statements on this issue for people who know Minister Tuckey as well as I do.

I need to say a little about the conservation agreement that was put together in Western Australia. We heard from Senator Forshaw, who spent a lot of time not dealing with the motion but talking about how many RFAs Mr Tuckey had put together. Whatever the number is, it is absolutely and totally the full sum more than what you people put in place when you were in government.
Senator Forshaw interjecting—

talk.start.para: —When you were in government, you did not put any in place. Your score is zero, zero, zero. And even if you add zero onto that, it stays zero. What I have done before in this place is give credit to you for the national forest policy statement and for bringing on the JANIS criteria, which we on this side of the chamber supported. But you appear now to have walked away from them, because the Western Australian RFA that was signed by Premier Court and Mr Howard is the one that most closely resembles the policy positions in them. If I have time in this debate, I will go to some of those points.

speech.para: I now turn to a further enlightening issue in this motion and whether it is Mr Tuckey who is doing the inflaming. I will give you the answer that was given by Premier Court when he was asked this question. He said:
"No I don't, and I want to just put something on record there—
and this was after there was full-scale disagreement between Minister Tuckey—the federal government—and the Western Australian government—

because we've had one side of this argument in relation to these protests. The timber workers have had incredible control . . . self control, for the last few years, while the sections of the green movement have been using quite dangerous and outrageous tactics. And I think the time's come when the media should spell out, in detail, what some of these green protesters have been doing."

And the quote goes on. Once again, the Premier of Western Australia—in this dispute with the federal government about the signing of that agreement—has gone on the public record and put to bed the claims in this motion. I want to appeal to senators to remember that censure motions should not come before this place lightly. If they are going to be debated, we should make the decision on the facts before us—not on somebody's preconceived position on what they would like the RFA to be. I respect your position on RFAs, Senator Brown, and it is quite different from mine. I believe the two can work together. But you are so wrong to move this motion in this form, because it misses the mark and it misses the point.

Quite a deal has been said about Mr Burrows. I do not condone either situation. I think it is very sad that both of them have happened. But we have to have a balanced view when we are dealing with these issues. We cannot take the violent aspects of one side and walk away from the other side.

We hear a lot about community support, political support and so on, but I want to acknowledge that there is at least one person who has made his position absolutely clear—and I know there are others in Western Australia who have walked right away from Dr Gallop on this matter. I refer to Mark Nevill. This is a newspaper quote regarding Mr Nevill:
He accused the ALP leadership of chasing new voters by ignoring its traditional constituency and, in the case of the forests issue, rejecting working people.

That is a very important statement, because it reflects on the forest side of Minister Tuckey's responsibilities and the fact that, having had an RFA put in place, these people were entitled to expect some certainty about what happened. Those people are not traditional Liberal Party supporters. In fact, I had the beautiful experience—and they were virtually all AWU and CFMEU members—of being cheered at a rally that I spoke at, because we were standing up for the timber workers, something that the Labor Party in Western Australia seem to have forgotten. If they had stood up for fairness for their workers—in terms of your own national forest policy statement and your JANIS criteria—

talk.start.para: —I think you've said enough.

—You might think that but I do not. If they had stood by that agreement we would not have the situation we have today. You have to feel for people in towns who have no option, who have had their real estate values totally swept away. Schools will close. All the various things that go in the context of this will occur. I had a lady from down there ring me up a couple of weeks ago. She said to me, `I signed my mortgage the day before the RFA was effectively torn up. What am I going to do? I have a legal document; can I tear that up too?' Of course she cannot tear it up, and these are the sad stories that come out of this.
—Go and see Court.

—I have seen him, don't worry about that. We will hear an enormous number of very sad and unfortunate stories. If you lose one, two or three children from a school then you lose a teacher. It is not like living in a metropolitan area; the impacts of these things are quite different. I say to Mark Nevill: good on you. I would not be surprised to see a few more go with him. I can tell you right now that you, the Labor Party, have a very disgruntled Julian Grill in Western Australia, as you people well know.

speech.para: There are many things we could go on about in this debate, but it is my very strong view that—and I want to sum this up—there has not been a sustainable case made for this censure motion. In fact, the reverse is the situation. It has not been Minister Tuckey who has been inciting violence in this matter. He took a very opposite position, as I have spelt out very clearly. In terms of the incitement, I find it deplorable that some of our wealthiest people in Perth in Western Australia went down there and incited people to feel very angry about how they have been treated and about how they have had their jobs just swept under the carpet after an agreement was put in place and signed off. Dr Keith Woollard came out and said, `At the end of the day I don't really care about those particular facts.'

In summing up, there is no evidence of inflammatory statements in any of the tape recordings of Minister Wilson Tuckey; there is no evidence produced in any of the newspapers—none whatsoever. You can look at the transcript of the Peter Kennedy interview done after the rally at Parliament House where he spoke. You can look at the ABC interview with Eion Cameron. You can work through all these things and no case has been put. Nor has a case been argued. There is criticism of the RFA process as it existed, and we have heard that before. There has been criticism because the RFA legislation before us has not gone through, but that is nothing to do with the resolution before us.

I once again appeal to the Democrats and the other people here on this matter: censure motions should not be taken lightly. They should not even be on the Notice Paper unless you can back them up with evidence and facts. If this motion is carried, it will demean the quality, the meaning and the impact of a censure motion, because the people listening and the people out there will know darn well that it has been put here on false pretences and false grounds and that it has no substance which would allow it to be carried with credibility.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to this censure motion I reiterate that this is not to be taken as my first speech. I will be as brief and as to the point as I can. This is not a forum for further debate on the forests issue; it is specifically a debate on the behaviour of the Minister for Forestry and Conservation outlined in the motion before us. The Democrats support this motion because we believe that censure of this minister is richly deserved. Senator Crane asks that the Democrats, in particular, do not take this lightly. I say: we do not. We do not take any decision lightly, particularly given our position in the current chamber.

speech.para: What is at the core of this motion is the behaviour of the minister—not the issues surrounding him—and most particularly how it relates to Western Australia. The regional forest agreement is no doubt a very contentious and highly emotive issue, but it is precisely because of that that the minister must be reasonable, sensitive and diplomatic. If only that were possible from this minister.

I recall that, some years ago, after the tragedy of Port Arthur, the federal government moved to introduce gun control. That too was a contentious and difficult issue for some people. In part, it resulted in a rally of many hundreds of people in my home city which, for reasons that I do not understand, degenerated into a forum for homophobia as speaker after speaker claimed that gun control was some kind of strange conspiracy orchestrated by the gay community. People outside and inside this rally held banners and posters which read `Register poofters, not guns'. The guest speaker at that rally was Mr Tuckey, who echoed the sentiments of all those at this meeting and argued for the principle that gun owners should not be registered whereas gay men should be. As a gay man and an advocate for my community, I know personally the chilling effect that has on people and on communities. I have seen first hand how irrational, intolerant statements from public figures affect people in the wider community.

If the recent statements by Minister Tuckey had been made by an ordinary citizen, perhaps they would not have mattered so much. If a citizen had expressed the view that the greenies or the loggers were wrong, fine; that is public debate. But when a minister makes the specific claim, `Those people down there don't respect the law; why should anyone else?' referring to the conflict between the loggers and the forest preservationists, then it stands to reason that there is a cause and effect between that intolerant statement and the violence that resulted only days afterwards.

This motion is not specifically a referendum as such or a motion specifically asking us to decide whether or not the minister is right or wrong in his arguments. What is in question is his behaviour. The Democrats argue, and I argue, that, whatever Minister Tuckey may think, it is what he says that is most important, and what is needed right now in this emotive and divisive debate is a sense of leadership, tolerance and respect, none of which this minister has shown. For that reason we support the motion.

talk.start.para: —I too would like to take the opportunity to speak on this censure motion. We have in Minister Tuckey a person who really likes conflict. He is a person who loves a blue. He has never engaged in consensus politics in his life. He has never supported consensus politics—he probably does not know what consensus politics is. Of course, he is known to his friends and foes alike as `Iron Bar' Tuckey because he has got such a long history of confrontation and antagonism, a long history of inflaming sensitive situations for his own perceived political ends. I do not think anyone is unaware of the history that surrounds Mr Tuckey. He has a deserved reputation in his own electorate, in the Liberal Party and in Australian politics for his approach to the political and parliamentary process.

speech.para: The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, knows Mr Tuckey very well and is well aware of this sort of approach. After all, Mr Tuckey was one of the key conspirators against Mr Howard, one of the Peacock conspirators who openly boasted of his role in bringing down Mr Howard from the Liberal Party leadership and installing Mr Peacock in the behind closed doors Liberal Party coup. There is just no subtlety about Mr Tuckey. There is no delicate touch about Mr Tuckey. There is no deftness in dealing with difficult and sensitive issues from Mr Tuckey. He is the bluntest of political instruments imaginable.

On the forest issue he has been a loose cannon. He has been absolutely out of control. I would say, let's face it, he is bonkers; he is absolutely bonkers. When Mr Howard decides to bring Mr Tuckey into this sensitive portfolio, is it a stroke of political genius on Mr Howard's part to bring in Mr Tuckey to one of the most sensitive and important portfolios in the government, that of forestry and conservation? What he has done in this portfolio from day one is to act consistently in bad faith. The regional forest agreements in Victoria and Tasmania, while I do not think anyone from any side of the argument would consider them to be perfect, at least have been implemented with as little pain, including as little pain to the government, as possible. But that was, of course, before we had Mr Tuckey enter the field. That was the tactical genius in bringing Mr Tuckey into this area of ministerial responsibility. That meant that the next RFA in line, the one in Mr Tuckey's own backyard in Western Australia, he immediately turned into a political bushfire, which is still burning out of control thanks to Mr Tuckey. What do you expect, I suppose, if you bring someone like Mr Tuckey into something so delicate and serious as negotiations around regional forest agreements? It is the approach that Mr Tuckey has always adopted—that is, a bull in a china shop.

I think many would agree that the inflaming and inciting of timber workers who find themselves in a difficult situation in relation to the Western Australian Regional Forest Agreement is simply unconscionable. I think that ought to be placed on record. I have got no idea what was in the Prime Minister's mind when he brought Mr Tuckey back from overseas to fix a bushfire that was really already out of control. It was an argument that the Prime Minister had ignited himself in an exchange of insults with the Premier of Western Australia, the Liberal Party's Mr Richard Court. You would think the Prime Minister must have known what would be the inevitable result of bringing someone like Tuckey back to get him involved. I would say that the responsibility for the mess that we have lies equally with Mr Howard and Mr Tuckey. You cannot leave Mr Howard off the hook in this. I remember reading this in the West Australian newspaper on 29 July 1999:

Forestry Minister Wilson Tuckey has vowed to lock up $15 million in Federal money earmarked to help the timber industry in retaliation for the Western Australian Government's about-face on the Regional Forest Agreement.

The next day in the same newspaper we read that Mr Howard had moved to tone down Mr Tuckey's fighting words, claiming that Mr Tuckey would not withdraw the money to punish Western Australia, but he left open the possibility of change to the financial arrangement as a result of the new deal. So you had the Prime Minister trying to dig Mr Tuckey out of a hole on that one.
We have mentioned in the Senate before the fact that one of the matriarchs of the Liberal Party, Dame Rachel Cleland, bagged the appointment of Wilson Tuckey. She said:

Howard appointed Wilson Tuckey with the specific duty of doing the best he can for the industry against all the people who want to keep the forests. "You can't respect a man who does that, and that's Howard, whom I once did respect. I think that he is governing an Australia that no longer exists. He is governing in his own mind an Australia that existed 30 years ago."
This was said by Dame Rachel back on 30 April this year, when this was all starting to warm up in Western Australia. You now have the Western Australian division of the Liberal Party in meltdown.

I am surprised that Senator Crane wanted to get into the censure motion debate today. After all, he has a preselection to try to protect over there. Perhaps he has no hope of winning it anyway and he thinks he cannot make any more enemies than he already has. I commend Senator Crane for his courage in getting involved in the debate, because he basically said that the whole of the state division of the Liberal Party was completely wrong in their approach to this important issue.

But Mr Tuckey is always taking on members of the Liberal Party and his coalition colleagues. He took on John Anderson. He claimed that the RFA issue was heating up because Mr Anderson was too busy in a big portfolio to give forestry his full attention and to stop greens hijacking the debate, so he had added the responsibility to Mr Tuckey. Mr Tuckey bagged Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. I read in the Age newspaper:

Tuckey says he and Robert Hill are now like two lawyers presenting both sides of the case to John Howard as the judge who decides the final form of the agreements. Sources say that as recently as this month Howard declared in Cabinet that the bottom line in the forests debate was regional jobs.

Senator Hill got his office to come out and say that they were `bemused' by the idea that Mr Tuckey was needed to keep the process on track, pointing out that the earlier RFAs in Victoria and Tasmania were relatively uncontroversial, unlike those in Western Australia and New South Wales after Mr Tuckey had been appointed. Then we read that he had clashed heatedly on a couple of occasions with Ms Tehan, the state conservation minister in Victoria, over the accuracy of her department's calculations on the sustainable yield of timber available for public native forests.

But they all pale into insignificance compared with the absolute bucketing that Mr Tuckey has deservedly got from his coalition colleagues. You notice that, with the exception of Senator Crane, all the other Liberals from Western Australia are completely silent. That is significant. They are silent on the issue, with the exception of poor old Senator Crane—no-one has told him that Richard Court and the other mob over there have got the numbers. But apart from Senator Crane, no-one in the Western Australian Liberal Party stands ready, willing or able to come out and support Mr Tuckey, because he is indefensible.
Senator Crane interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I do not know if you read today's West Australian editorial on this issue. I did. This is obviously a very dominant issue in the political environment in Western Australia. The editorial said:

speech.para: Indeed, reports of balaclava-wearing thugs wielding weapons, of a photographer's arm being seized and an attack on a conservationists' centre with an incendiary device send a shudder down the spines of most Australians.
I am sure that is right, although they do not send a shudder through Senator Crane and Mr Tuckey. It said:
State Environment Minister Cheryl Edwardes believes Federal Forestry and Conservation Minister Wilson Tuckey's comments have inflamed the situation—and she is partially right.
Mr Tuckey is not noted for adopting a conciliatory approach to problems and many people fail to understand why Prime Minister John Howard appointed him to such a sensitive portfolio.
That is true—the West Australian newspaper has that one absolutely right. It went on:

His continual attacks on Richard Court, Geoff Gallop, Hendy Cowan, Cheryl Edwardes—indeed, anybody who does not see the forestry issue his way—has made him plenty of enemies and done his cause little good.

It is not sufficient for Mr Tuckey to deny that he incited violence. Government ministers have a duty—and none more so than during such emotionally charged situations—to choose carefully words for public consumption. We expect them to lead by example and to ameliorate society's trouble spots, not exacerbate them.
Mr Tuckey, however, prefers to employ words like anarchy, disaster and war when talking about the problems.
That says it all, that is what this is all about and that is why we have a censure motion in the Senate today about this particular minister.

Earlier this afternoon, my colleague Senator Ray raised, first of all, the important question about the appropriateness or otherwise of this matter going through without debate. There is no question that you can devalue a censure motion to the extent of it just being carried or defeated on the voices. If you are going to present a censure motion, you have to state your case. Debate is required on a motion of such significance and I think that was accepted by Senator Brown, the mover of the motion.

But, of course, the other issue my colleague Senator Ray raised was the question of whether the Senate should get into the business of moving censure motions on members of the executive in the House of Representatives. That is an important issue. Of course, you only have to go back to the record to see what the approach of the coalition itself has been on that important issue. On 25 May 1989, we had Senator Newman move and carry a censure motion on the then Minister for Defence and Senator Richardson. On 5 November 1992, we had Senator Hill move and have carried a rather extraordinary censure motion on the then Prime Minister, Mr Keating. It had the Senate censuring Mr Keating for degrading the office of Prime Minister and the institution of parliament in his contemptuous abuse of the Senate. Well, if we are talking about contemptuous abuse, we ought to have a look at Mr Tuckey and all the targets he identifies. But that was carried, and you had the usual suspects such as Senator Campbell, Senator Crane and others rocking up to vote for that.

A censure motion was moved by Senator Campbell on 10 May 1994, censuring Mr McMullan and Mr Walker for the non-production of documents. Again, the speakers in this debate, Senator Abetz, Senator Crane and the now Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Campbell, voted on that and happily agreed to that. And we had a censure motion on the then minister for transport, Mr Brereton, in which, again, the same suspects rolled up and happily supported it. So it has become the practice of the chamber.

It is true to say that censure motions in this place have been devalued. There is no doubt about this. We had the extraordinary circumstance earlier when Senator Bolkus, a member of the opposition executive, was censured by this chamber at the same time that the government was arguing that we had so many pressing matters before the chamber in terms of the legislative program. So the government, of course, has devalued the censure motion. But, as far as the opposition are concerned, we do try to approach these questions on their merit and, if a censure motion is worthy of passage, we will vote for it, regardless of whether it has been moved by a non-Labor, non-government, senator or not. I thought we had a very poor case mounted in the censure motion on Senator Hill but the opposition was able to fire up the case, which was not adequately argued by the Australian Democrats on that occasion, and, on balance, we decided to support that censure motion.

But the motion before us today is whether the Senate should censure the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, Mr Tuckey, for inflaming rather than mitigating the conflict over Western Australia's regional forest agreements. We will just look at the record here: I am afraid that Mr Tuckey has been confrontationist. He has been inflammatory. He has done everything he can to promote conflict and confrontation on an important issue that requires sensitive handling from any minister who has responsibility for it.

We all know the forest debate is one of the most difficult to handle; it is one of the most difficult public policy issues that we have in this country. It was ever thus. But it is never helped by people coming in, like Mr Tuckey has—a loose cannon; someone who is completely out of control in the way he approaches his ministerial responsibility. He just does not have the touch for it. He does not have the capacity. He is either unwilling or unable to put in the effort to this important task that he has responsibility for, in the way it should be put in, to ensure that these difficult issues are handled in the best interests of all Australians.

It is not too hard, in many senses, to incite people in this debate, and I will be the first to acknowledge that timber workers particularly are facing difficult challenges and difficult situations. That is true in Western Australia, as it is in some other places, and this constant balance between conservation interests and industry interests is something that governments of all political persuasions have struggled with. On this occasion, Mr Tuckey has failed miserably. His performance has been disgraceful. As I say, I think he is bonkers, and we support the censure motion.

talk.start.para: —in reply—The passage of this debate has convinced me that I have made the right move in bringing forward a motion to censure this failed minister. Not only has the minister failed on the basis of the half of his portfolio which is conservation, and not even members on his side of this chamber moved to defend that contention; he is a failure as minister for conservation. But when it comes to his role in the other half of his portfolio, that of minister for forestry, there has been no good argument brought forward in this chamber to show that he has been able to discharge his duties there with effect. In fact, he has worsened the situation for the industry itself, not least for those who are working in the industry and who feel, very properly, concerned about their jobs. What we have heard is that, since the passage of RFAs—and this has not been contended anywhere in this debate—before, after and during this minister's tenure, the number of jobs lost in the industry has mounted into the hundreds. The minister has been ineffective in being able to stop that haemorrhage, despite the promise that he brought to his portfolio of ensuring the jobs of the people in the industry.

speech.para: So great is that failure that he has before this parliament a bill on regional forest agreements which offers massive compensation to city based woodchip corporations if they are unable, because of federal intervention, to cut forests in the future. But the bill has not one word of support or succour for workers in the industry in terms of guaranteeing their jobs, their livelihoods and their future—nothing at all under this minister.

In particular, it is the purport of this argument that, rather than helping the debate, this minister has inflamed it and made it worse for everyone. That purport has been endorsed not just by this side of the parliament through cogent argument, but by the failure of those on the other side to defend the minister. Not one minister on the other side got up to defend Minister Tuckey on this issue. Two members got up to defend him, but they failed in their contribution to this debate to tackle—let alone to defend—the central purport, which is that Mr Tuckey has inflamed and worsened this issue for everybody involved in the debate, in particular in his home state of Western Australia.

I cannot help but conclude from that that there is a covert wish by members on the other side that this motion—which they have to, of course, oppose—will in fact succeed, that this will give some leverage and open up the way for the removal of this minister from a ministry which he has so failed that it has led to uproar within his own party in Western Australia. He is at loggerheads as much with the Court government in Western Australia and the ministers involved in this important public debate as he is with conservationists. The majority of people in that state, as in other states, want the forest defended while the governments involved move to the win-win situation of relocating this industry to the plantation base in Australia. This base is ready and waiting, if properly exploited, to provide all the wood needs of this country and, with downstream processing, stop the haemorrhage of jobs—to turn it around so we see an increase in jobs and stability in the job figures in this country. The minister has failed.

I add finally that you can gain from the tenor of debate we have just heard that there are concerns on all sides of this parliament that the recent events which involved violence and threat to citizens in this country might not have occurred had the inflammatory contribution of this minister not preceded them. If we do not speak up about his performance, we will ipso facto be responsible for even worse that might occur further down the line. Our job is to not allow that to happen. The removal of this minister would go a long way towards taking the heat out of the debate and returning more light. We cannot remove the minister, but we can censure him. If the Prime Minister, who appointed him some time ago, has good political sense and takes into account the good sense of the people, he will allow this censure motion—if it succeeds, as I believe it will—to help him make the important decision of removing this minister from office.

The speeches read as follows—
SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT (DISPOSAL OF ASSETS) BILL 1999
This Government is committed to the effective delivery of its assistance measures, and part of this involves encouraging more responsible attitudes in the community.

As foreshadowed in the 1999 Budget, this bill amends the Social Security Act 1991 to introduce improvements to the provisions which prescribe how much a person can dispose of by way of gifts and still remain qualified for assistance from the public purse.

Currently, the Social Security Act 1991 allows a person or a couple to give away up to $10,000 per pension year before the gift begins to impact on the level of assistance. This annual $10,000 "free area" is anomalous, in that it is greater than the maximum single pension rate—some $9,400 per annum. The result is that under the current rules an income support recipient can give away more than that person is entitled to receive by way of assistance. Needless to say, this loophole has become a favourite tool for many financial planners who exploit it to increase the income support entitlement of their customers.

This bill will close this loophole by reducing the annual "free area" to $5,000, with effect from 1 July 1999. However, provision is made in the bill to ensure that any income support paid on the basis of the existing disposal rules before the Royal Assent to the bill, is protected from being recovered from the income support recipient insofar as these amendments are concerned.
At the same time, the bill will take the opportunity to change the basis of the concession from "pension year" to the more widely understood "financial year".
I commend the bill to the Senate.
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1999

The purpose of the amendments to the Plant Breeder's Rights Act 1994 (PBR Act) is to: provide temporary relief for applications made ineligible when the PBR Act was introduced; improve public accessibility of information; clarify aspects of prior sale and the payment of fees; and to correct minor transcription errors.

The amendments are of a minor technical nature and are aimed at improving the efficient operation of the PBR scheme. They have wide industry support and have been endorsed by the Plant Breeders Rights Advisory Committee.

The Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 has, as its main purpose, measures that allow cost effective and efficient levy and charge collection techniques. It provides a single act to deal with all levy and charge collection. It allows for uniformity of collection methods and permits a consistency of approach to procedural matters.
Many of the amendments clarify and update customs used in rural industries; such as the use of settlement agents and solicitors in arranging property sales incorporating the sale of live-stock.

Anomalies have been highlighted as to who is legally the proprietor or operator of a processing establishment, particularly an abattoir. A person who holds a licence under State or Territories' law will, for levy collection purposes, be deemed to be the proprietor. If a licence is not mandatory, the proprietor is to be the person carrying on the business of operating the processing establishment.

The powers for authorised persons are being upgraded to bring them into line with those used by inspectors under the Export Control Act 1982. For example, new offences for non-cooperation or obstructing an authorised person in performing those duties are to be included.
The remaining amendments merely expand and clarify existing provisions.

The purpose of amendments to the Natural Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Act 1992 is to change the name of the National Landcare Advisory Committee established under the act to the Australian Landcare Council.

In July 1997 the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon John Anderson MP announced that the National Landcare Advisory Committee was to be called the Australian Landcare Council. The amendment has support of those involved with the Australian Landcare Council and the new name has been in use since the announcement of the intended change.

The Schedule in the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991, which provides for the establishment of a Grains Industry Council, is to be repealed. The need for a forum to advise the Government on the strategic direction of the grains industry is no longer relevant following privatisation of the Australian Wheat Board and on-going reforms to State grain marketing arrangements.
The purpose of the amendments to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992 are to change the role, functions and name of the advisory body currently known as the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council.

The Rural Adjustment Act 1992 provides for the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) and the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council (RASAC). As the RAS effectively ceased to operate as at 30 June 1998, being replaced by the Government's Agriculture—Advancing Australia package, the title and functions of RASAC have been reconsidered.
The amendments propose that the new advisory council will be providing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry with advice on the following matters:
. rural adjustment generally;
. regional issues, particularly matters regarding entering into agreements with States relating to rural adjustment;
. matters relating to declarations of exceptional circumstances;
. training issues, and in particular the Farm Business Improvement Program; and
. any other matter that the Minister requests advice or information about.

The amendments to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 expand and clarify a number of definitions under the act as well as performing a few housekeeping functions to ensure the provisions of the act are consistent.

Key changes are to the definitions of "examinable document" and "wine premises", and to Section 39W, which sets out the records required to be kept. These amendments are designed to ensure that all relevant details of a wine's transformation from grape to retail sale are duly recorded and that all documents and records relevant to the claims made on wine labels can be inspected. These changes do not seek to add extra regulation on wine businesses but simply to reinforce the requirements already set out in the act.
